Every worker wore the prescribed vestments, every truck unloaded according to ancient rite. The smallest deviation could send ripples through the whole operation like a stone dropped in still water.

The second link was supply, a thing of strategy and partnership. Managers would sit in their towers and determine what each facility could do best, like generals plotting campaigns. Sometimes they'd reach out to other companies, forging alliances in pursuit of what they called velocity - that holy grail of quality and flexibility wedded to the twin gods of cost and efficiency. The divisions were many, each with its own machines and men, its own specialties honed sharp as knives. These decisions too could make or break a company, send it soaring or drag it down into the dust of bankruptcy.

They came in those times the great tomes bound in leather and gilt, stories of drawing rooms and high society folk wrought with detail and ceremony like some terrible pageant. Yet there were others. Dark tales. Tales of foundlings and orphans and the mad people on the moors. Oliver Twist and Wuthering Heights stood apart from the rest, carried within them something older and more terrible. Something that gave power to their people on the page, showed what drove them and what ate at their souls like carrion birds.

He walked between Sikes and Crackit and they argued, their voices like wind through dead leaves, and he knew he spoke to them though he could not hear his own voice. Then came the gunshot. A sound like God's own thunder. Shouts rose up and lights bloomed in the darkness and something unseen took him away through the chaos and the night. Through it all pain walked with him like some dark companion, never leaving, never sleeping.

The books showed these fever dreams, these visions that came like prophets in the night. In Oliver Twist they revealed the boy's heart, showed what pained him and what truths he knew about the world of thieves and murderers around him. When the shooting came again in the twenty-eighth chapter Oliver lived it anew, dreamlike, while he sought help that might not come. The passage told of his powerlessness, how the events moved through him like a river through a canyon, unstoppable. His mind fractured and he saw Sikes and Crackit again, fever-wrought apparitions in the dark. The shot came again but this time the pain was already there, dwelling in his flesh like some unwanted tenant. He was carried away by hands he could not see and did not fight against. The question hung in the air like smoke - whose will had brought this about? Not Oliver's. Never Oliver's. He had become something acted upon, not an actor. Fagin's influence had worked its way into him like poison, teaching him defeat, teaching him despair.

The day went and the darkness came. No day at all really. Just a brief lightning flash of light between seas of darkness. Night came on again vast and terrible in its silence yet brief in its hours.

I reckon it was two years past when I worked with them children after their schoolin was done for the day. Them that needed help with their studies. English and readin was what I knew best and one day this instructor come to me about a boy. Adrian was his name. Third or fourth grade, I dont recall which. The boy had trouble with his letters and I watched him struggle with the shapes on the page like they was some ancient text carved in stone by forgotten peoples. Some letters he knew true as sunrise but others might as well been hieroglyphs cut deep in obsidian. He spoke English pure as any native son but his blood was Latino, that much was certain.

We worked at it day after day until his mother come in one afternoon while the others was gone on some excursion. She stood there in the doorway like a dark bird, not a word of English in her. Just Spanish flowing like water from a deep well. My own Spanish was poor but we managed somehow and thats when it hit me like God's own thunder - the boy could read fine enough but the English alphabet was foreign country to him. Whether this knowledge ever served him I cant say.

This here story speaks to something deeper in these borderlands, specially in California where the tongue of one land bleeds into another. Sometimes the wall between languages aint as clear as we might think. Even them children who speak English like they was born to it sometimes cant read the words proper. We all know this truth but what's to be done? For Adrian it was simple enough - teach him his letters and sounds in English. But for them that barely speak the language its like trying to build a house in quicksand. Aint no single answer neither. Dual language learning, throwing em in with English speakers, private teaching, special classes - none of these alone is gonna fix what's broke. The answer lies in weaving them all together like strands in a rope.

The dual language way of teaching, that's something worth considering. Not just for them Spanish speakers but for all of em. Studies show these children do better than their peers though some folk fear it like they fear what they dont understand. They say its wasteful but they're wrong as wrong can be. If we was to make this the way of things instead of just sometimes, every child would grow stronger for it. But how to do such a thing? We cant expect every teacher to speak both tongues - that aint realistic. But there aint no reason we cant have helpers who do.

From youth we are told of something greater than ourselves. Something vast and unknowable that stretches beyond the boundaries of mind and reason. They shepherd the young ones to wooden buildings with crosses hung like dead things on the walls or to temples where old men murmur ancient words in tongues long forgotten. Some take what their fathers gave them and hold it close like a talisman against the dark while others cast it away declaring themselves alone in the void. All of them searching. All of them lost.

The old man said cardinal and the word hung there in the wet air between us. We sat watching the rain beat against the tin roof like tiny fists demanding entry, the water coursing through the gutters and drowning the flowers that mother had planted years ago before she too was gone. His eyes fixed on some distant point where memory and rain became one thing. The clothes that once fit him proper now hung loose on bones that seemed too sharp beneath his skin. The hair thin and grey where once it had been thick and black. Neither of us spoke of what was coming. Neither of us could bear to make it real with words. I moved my chair closer to his and together we watched the rain fall through the June darkness like tears from an indifferent god.

He died in December. Five days after I turned twenty-two years old. The doctors with their medicines and machines had kept him breathing past their own predictions but what good was breath without peace. What kind of god would craft such torment. In the darkness I spoke no prayers for I knew if there was a god he had turned from us long ago like a father abandoning his children to wolves.

I did not watch him die. Could not watch the body that had made me turn cold and still. Memory is a cruel thing that shows us what we most wish to forget and I wanted only to remember him alive. He would not have wanted me there anyway. His only child watching the light go out of him. I lay in my bed for three days waiting for word.

No word came.

The man Taylor of Caroline walked in the early light of the Republic like a pilgrim seeking truth in barren fields. He was a tiller of soil first and always but the earth and brief congress with matters of state had forged in him something hard and crystalline and pure. His voice rang clear against the gathering dark of federal power and rang clear for the freedom of men to work their own destiny. The soil was his scripture and from it he drew all manner of revelation about how men ought govern themselves.

He saw in this new land a terrible possibility. Here there were no ancient ghosts to bind the minds of men, no rotting institutions to poison the well of self-governance. He held that men were born with certain rights sacred and inviolable and these rights moved together like a school of fish, each one depending on the others, and should one be taken the rest would surely follow leaving naught but empty water behind. These freedoms, he declared, must remain forever beyond the reach of any government fashioned by human hands.

Taylor knew the duality that lived in the hearts of men. Good and evil dwelled there like conjoined twins sharing one heart, and any government worth its salt must account for both. He wrote that government being the work of men must carry in it all the virtue and vice that men possess. The principles he called good were those that protected what a man owned and worked for, that made the earth yield its bounty, that kept the moneylenders from the temple. He believed even corrupt men serving in a righteous system would be bound to do right, though their hearts might burn with greed.

Like a prophet in the wilderness he called for the Constitution to be read pure and clean, stripped of all ornament and interpretation. The federal beast must be kept small and lean lest it grow fat on the wealth of the people and turn tyrannical. But he warned against reading the words too simply, for without understanding the minds of those who wrote them, even holy words could be twisted to serve unholy ends. And above all other documents he held high the Declaration, for in it he saw written clear as morning light the truth that these states were sovereign and separate, not one nation but many joined in common cause.

He stood and looked down and the looking was a thing without emotion or connection to the world of men. His mind moved like water over stones, touching but never holding, seeing but never knowing. Thoughts came and went like wind through dead grass.

Once there had been a book. Some artist had given it to him. Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain it was called and in it were the secrets of how men make pictures from the world. How they take the chaos of creation and put it in a box. How they frame God's work in squares of their own making. Take a kitchen with its bowl of fruit and make it something else. Something smaller. Something a man could understand.

But there wasnt no frame for what he saw now. No box to put it in. No way to make it smaller or more manageable. It just was what it was and he stood before it like a pilgrim at a shrine he never wanted to find. Picasso had his blues and Monet his greens but what lay before him now was brown. Brown like the earth. Brown like death.

His fingers found the handle. Touched it like a gunslinger touching steel. The water moved in its porcelain bowl like some imprisoned sea. Matter broke away and scattered and was gone. He flushed again. The brown thing stayed. Stuck there like original sin. Like something that had always been there and always would be.

He stood in his green tie that choked at his throat like a hangman's rope. Stood and looked at what some nameless pilgrim had left behind in this Rite Aid temple. The toilet paper came off the roll like bandages for the dead. He wrapped his hand until it was white as bone. Bent like a man in prayer. Reached into that water like reaching into hell itself...

They die on the roads. Young ones. Their blood dark and pooling on asphalt while chrome glints in the dying light. The men in white coats and their papers speak of minds not yet formed, of brains still raw and reaching. Inexperience sits like a demon in the passenger seat. The vehicle rolls. It speeds. It leaves the known path for darker territories.

They travel in packs, these young ones. Like wolves but without the wisdom. Numbers from men who study such things in California tell a truth that any fool could see - that death rides closer when youth congregates behind glass and steel.

The state men tried to fix it with paper laws. No driving in darkness. No carrying others who share their tender age. But these are just words on paper, thin as ash and just as lasting.

The truth sits harder. These children, these drivers barely weaned from their mothers' breast, cannot bear the weight of steel and speed and responsibility. Even at eighteen, says the doctor man Zuckerman, the blood runs too hot. The need for danger pulses like a second heart. Wait, he says. Wait until the fire cools.

If we dont wait, if we keep putting keys in hands still soft with youth, the roads will drink more blood. The children of the boom times are coming, millions strong, ready to take their turn at the wheel of death.

The fix is simple but hard like all true things. Keep them from the wheel until eighteen summers have passed. Let them learn in classrooms and watched spaces. Make them prove their worth with hours behind the wheel under watchful eyes. California demands its pound of flesh - six hours watched and fifty more with elders present. Let it be so everywhere, from sea to burning sea.

This aint new thinking. But truth rarely is.

They called it CAPD and it was a thing that lived in the brain and made the world sound wrong. Not wrong like deafness or the absence of sound but wrong in the way that the mind takes what it hears and makes sense of it. Like a broken translator working between the ear and the understanding.

The disorder stood three-legged. First was what it was. Then how they found it. Last was what teachers could do when they found such a child in their rooms, lost in the sound.

It began in the fifties when they didnt know what to call it. Italian doctors with names like prayers - Bocca, Calearo, Cassinari - they started testing children who could hear but couldnt understand what they heard. Then Kimura came with his tests of competing sounds in different ears like some kind of auditory inquisition.

The way it showed itself was manifold and terrible. Sometimes the afflicted couldnt tell where sounds came from in the world, like they lived in a universe without direction. Sometimes they couldnt tell one sound from another or recognize patterns that should have been clear as desert stars. They might miss the way a voice changes when it means something different than what the words say. Sound eating sound. Everything heard but nothing understood.

To find it they had to watch and test and measure. Audiologists and speech people and doctors all with their different tools like mechanics trying to diagnose an engine they couldnt see. They had questionnaires and tests but none of them perfect. None of them sure. They would put sounds in both ears at once and ask what was heard, like trying to catch two rabbits running in opposite directions. Sometimes they would measure the very electricity of hearing itself, tiny signals in the ear like distant lightning.

The children come to us broken and we aim to mend them though we know not how. They come with their eyes vacant and their spirits crushed by those who should have nurtured them. I seen it in my wanderings through the halls of human misery. The calling came to me as it comes to all who walk these paths. Service. Respect. A moral compass pointing true north in a world gone mad.

I walked among the lost souls in school halls watching them medicate their pain with whatever poison they could find. The darkness in their eyes spoke volumes no book could hold. After my schooling at Piedmont I drifted like a leaf on water until fate brought me to that house where the boy sat. Sixteen years old. Terror written across his face plain as scripture. His parents had done things. Things that leave marks deeper than flesh.

The law stood impotent. The badges gleaming dully in the afternoon sun as I spoke to them of psychology degrees and human suffering. They sent me in to speak with the parents who sat like guilty thieves in their own home spinning tales of manipulation and simple disputes that weren't simple at all. Their words hung in the air like smoke from a fire that had consumed something precious.

Justice is a word we use like a talisman against the darkness but the darkness comes anyway. Society preaches individuality while demanding conformity like some mad priest speaking in tongues. I fought back in my own way. Hair the color of nuclear sunsets. Steel through flesh marking rebellion. Standing with the outcasts and the different because different is what we all are under our masks of sameness. The world tells us to be alike but the soul screams for freedom. I heard that scream and answered it. Still do. Always will.

The sleep comes or it don't. That's what they say. But there are deeper truths buried in the mechanisms of slumber like old bones in the desert waiting to be found. This here document aims to lay bare two ways of seeing the sleepless curse that men call insomnia: through the cold lens of biology and through the twisted prism of society and culture that shapes us all.

They got these models see. One speaks to the blood and bone we inherit from our forebears, the other to the world that made us. The biological way looks at the coiled strands of life passed down through generations like some ancient curse, while the sociocultural way peers into the darkness of race and class and place where men make their beds.

Sleep ain't just one thing neither. It comes in varieties like species of venomous snakes, each with its own poison. Primary disorders they call em, related disorders, others that don't fit neat categories. The primary ones split two ways: Dyssomnias and Parasomnias, words that sound like incantations in some dead tongue. Insomnia's the first kind, where sleep runs from you like a spooked horse. Then there's Hypersomnia where wakefulness slips away like water through fingers, and Narcolepsy that strikes a man down where he stands.

Deep in the brain there's a place called the hypothalamus. That's where the truth of sleep lives, in little cells that carry something called orexin. Scientists, they took mice and found these things called GABAB receptors, like tiny gatekeepers deciding when sleep comes and when it don't. They found that when you mess with these gatekeepers one way, sleep follows like night follows day. When you mess with em another way, sleep comes easier than death in the desert.

This here's the cruel truth of it: some folks is born with broken gatekeepers, and all the societal progress in the world won't fix what's wrote in their genes. That's the kind of truth that can destroy a man's chances at school, at work, at life itself.

The university sprawled before me like some great concrete leviathan, its buildings stark and grey against the pallid Pennsylvania sky. Two and a half years I'd walked these grounds, four and a half semesters watching the seasons turn and fade. In my first year they'd placed me in East Halls, far out on the eastern frontier where civilization gave way to the emptiness beyond the stadium. The walk from Stuart Hall to Willard was a pilgrimage of sorts, twenty-five minutes through whatever weather God saw fit to cast down upon us, and He was not often kind in State College.

An older graduate told me once how it used to be, how vast empty spaces had stretched between East Halls and the rest of campus like some no man's land. Now steel and glass structures rose from where nothing had been - the new Creamery, medical buildings, apartments sprouting like weeds after rain. The campus grew like a living thing, consuming space, making distance itself an enemy to be reckoned with.

The bicycle came as salvation. Not just the machine itself but what it represented - freedom, movement, time stolen back from the void. A friend who'd returned to riding spoke of it like a man who'd found religion. Bikes are great, he'd said, the words carrying the weight of revelation. And he wasn't wrong. A simple bowl of oatmeal could fuel thirty miles of travel, the body and machine working in harmony like some perfect marriage of flesh and steel.

Living off campus now, as far removed as those eastern dorms had been, the bicycle proved itself daily. Thomas building lay twenty-five minutes distant by foot, but astride the bike it shrunk to five. Pollock Road cut through campus like an artery, the most direct route, though not always friendly to those who chose two wheels over two feet. Walking held its own virtues, but time was a currency I couldn't spare. The mathematics of it were simple and cruel - thirty minutes saved each day, two and a half hours each week, time that could be spent on more pressing matters than the slow procession from point to point across this concrete expanse.

They come for the mind first and then the soul. In Huxley's world the machines and money men had won and what remained was the hollow shell of humanity shuffling through prescribed motions like marionettes dancing to strings pulled by unseen masters. The World Controller stood above them all like some dark god of old, watching his charges stumble through their manufactured paradise.

The people there knew nothing of individual thought. They were born into bondage though they called it freedom. Conditioned from the start to chase pleasure like starved dogs after meat, never knowing the taste of true happiness. Marx had seen it coming. The homogeny of the masses, the reification of human spirit into commodity. Huxley took these warnings and built them into prophecy.

False consciousness they called it. The great lie that kept the common folk from seeing the chains that bound them. In this brave new world the Deltas and Gammas moved like cattle, their minds filled with whispered commands in the dark of night. Buy. Spend. Consume. The Controller's voice echoing in their dreams. Hegemony complete and absolute. The upper classes knew better perhaps but did nothing, save for the occasional lost soul like Bernard who saw through the veil but could not tear it down.

There was no love in this place. No true connection between souls. The characters moved through their lives like ghosts, hollow and without depth. Perhaps that was Huxley's point - that the marriage of technology and capital had stripped humanity of its essence. Men spoke of women as objects, measuring their worth in pneumatic qualities. Women boasted of encounters like keeping score. Each class content in their prison cells, believing the bars that held them were made of gold. They consumed and obeyed and marched in lines, forever chasing happiness that was always just beyond reach, while overhead the masters smiled their knowing smiles and the machines hummed their endless song.

Four years gone now since I sat in that room learning of Islam. The question hung there like smoke, heavy and acrid. Whether this faith carried violence in its bones. The years since those towers fell have shown strange metamorphosis in how we view these people, these believers. The hatred and fear giving way to something else, something more accepting, though perhaps no more true. Who could have known then that a man named Barack Obama, carrying Muslim blood in his veins, would seek to lead this nation.

The Prophet's tale gnaws at me. What they write of Muhammad stands against what history whispers. In the stories I knew, he was a conqueror, brutal and absolute, forcing men to bow before his god with sword and flame. Yet these pages paint him gentle, a lamb among wolves, suffering the slings of disbelief until truth drew men to him like moths to flame. The contradiction sits uneasy, like a bone caught in the throat.

They write of miracles. Mutton and milk multiplied like Christ's loaves and fishes. The same stories told again but with different names, as if truth could be borrowed and worn like a dead man's clothes. They seek to clothe their prophet in Christ's glory, thieves picking through the sacred stories of another faith.

The tales come filtered through many mouths, passed down like old coins growing smooth with handling. Each teller adds his mark until the truth, if ever there was truth, becomes lost in the telling. They say this makes the stories stronger. I say it makes them hollow, like footprints in sand slowly filled by wind.

What troubles me most is how they've made him soft, this warrior prophet. They've painted him meek and wise when history shows blood on his hands. I wonder if those who follow him now know the truth of how he built his kingdom. If they know what darkness lurks beneath the gentle words they've written.

The words of the Christ and what he held true in his days upon the earth were cast aside like chaff in the wind when the thinking men came after. They built their towers of thought and doctrine and they built them high and they built them strong but they built them not on the rock that was laid before. History shows this truth plain as bone bleached white in the desert sun. The world now turns faster and men's minds turn with it and they look upon the old ways with new eyes. There are those who cling to what their fathers taught them like drowning men to driftwood but their numbers grow thin and their voices grow weak.

Among the believers there will come a knowing. A knowing deep as wells in ancient places. They will seek to strip away the vestments that men have draped upon the naked truth of what the Nazarene spoke. It may take generations, may take centuries, but it will come as sure as winter follows autumn. The great wheel will turn backward. Like peeling an onion they will strip away the layers of doctrine one by one until naught remains but the raw heart of what Jesus brought forth from God before men began to speak in his name.

When this tide washes over the lands of the West like a great flood, carrying multitudes in its wake back to worship as they did in the time of Christ, the church will remain. But it will be changed. The countless branches of the tree will draw together, becoming one trunk again. Where there was division there will be unity. Where there was difference there will be likeness. The wheel of history has turned thus before. The Romans who fed Christians to lions came to bow before the cross. The land that once enslaved black men came to be led by them. And so too will Christianity turn back upon itself, seeking its source like a river trying to find its spring, and in that seeking it will make all things one again. But mark this truth - they will come to read the words of Christ not as stones carved with unchanging letters but as living things, full of meaning that shifts like light on water. This is what must be. But what came before? What world birthed this truth that men have buried under centuries of doctrine?

Look back far enough and you find only the Jews, keepers of the one God, believing themselves chosen, holding their scriptures sacred as their very breath. This was the soil from which Christianity grew, in those days when Rome's iron heel came down upon Jerusalem in the year 63 before the Christ. But even then the Jews were not one people in spirit. They had split like a log struck by lightning - Sadducees, Pharisees, Essenes, Zealots, and the common folk who outnumbered them all.

The Jungle speaks truth of man's nature, raw and festering with greed, a darkness that dwells in the marrow of our bones. Men look only to their own survival, their own prosperity, caring nothing for those beneath them who crawl in the dirt and shadows. This truth manifests most clearly in the factory lords, those iron-hearted masters of industry who seek only to build their empires higher, wider, deeper into the blood-soaked earth.

They care nothing for what they destroy. Nothing for who they destroy. Sinclair writes of their domain: "The line of buildings stood clear-cut and black against the sky; here and there out of the mass rose the great chimneys, with the river of smoke streaming away to the end of the world." These words paint the corruption that pours forth from their kingdom of steel and smoke, a miasma that chokes the very air and poisons all it touches. The factory lords watch unmoved as their waste - animal filth and rotting offal - flows like a river of death through Packingtown.

These masters of meat and bone show no mercy to those who labor in their halls of slaughter. They would sooner spill blood than spend coin, for "from top to bottom the place is simply a seething cauldron of jealousies and hatreds; there is no loyalty or decency anywhere about it, there is no place in it where a man counted for anything against a dollar." Workers are cast aside like spent shells, discarded without warning or care, left to wander the streets like specters of their former selves.

In those dark days no law stood between the workers and their masters' whims. No shield protected them from the machinery that claimed fingers, hands, lives. The people of Packingtown existed as cattle themselves, expected to endure whatever horrors befell them in those blood-soaked killing floors. Unions rose like carrion birds, feeding off the desperate and dying. The workers, mostly foreign-born, existed as slaves in all but name: "Here is a population, low-class and mostly foreign, hanging always on the verge of starvation and dependent for its opportunities of life upon the whim of men every bit as brutal and unscrupulous as the old-time slave drivers; under such circumstances, immorality is exactly as inevitable, and as prevalent, as it is under the system of chattel slavery."

They called it Dream-land and Poe knew it for what it was. He'd written it himself and called it among his better works though such things are for others to judge. In it he spoke of Thulé, that ancient place beyond knowing, a word pulled from Virgil's own pages where it marked the edge of all things known to the Greeks who saw only darkness beyond.

But there was something else. Something darker. The German writers had caught Poe's eye and among them stood Goethe like a dark tower against the literary sky. Arndt saw it too, writing in his own tome about how Poe had walked in Goethe's footsteps, taking what was there and making it his own.

Goethe himself was no small figure. The Oxford people wrote of him, of his Faust, that great work split between 1808 and the year death took him in 1832. Within those pages lay "The King of Thulé," a tale of a dying queen and the goblet she left behind. The king who loved her drank deep of his grief until at last he cast that cup into the darkness of the sea and followed it into death. It mirrored something in Poe's own soul, that darkness that came with drink and loss.

The word Thulé appears twice in all Poe's writings like twin stars in a black sky. Once in The Pit and Pendulum and twice more in Dream-land where it stands guard at beginning and end. These works, Poe's and Goethe's, they speak to each other across the void. In Dream-land the speaker walks through shadows where dead friends wait and color bleeds away to nothing, just as Goethe's king walked alone in his grief toward his own ending.

Poe knew Goethe's work. Had to know it. He spoke of Tennyson's admiration for the German master and in those days Goethe's words were everywhere, carried on the wind like autumn leaves, touching all who would listen.

The law speaks of malice and rights and consequences but the truth of it was simpler than all that. The store manager sat in his office eating while the applesauce lay spilled and glistening on the cold linoleum like some viscous warning sign that no one heeded. They told him twice. First Wayne and then the Haddigan woman and both times he waved them away like bothersome flies, saying he had no time for such things while he ate his dinner in the fluorescent glare of his small kingdom.

The woman Palmer came through at half past five that evening. She walked the aisles like any other soul seeking sustenance in this temple of commerce, unknowing of what waited for her in aisle six. The applesauce lay there still, patient and malevolent as a serpent. When she fell it was as if the floor itself had reached up and pulled her down, her spine cracking against the hard surface like a branch in winter.

The law of California speaks of punitive damages and speaks too of malice and oppression and fraud, words ancient as scripture but new-minted for each fresh harm. Six others had fallen in that store that year alone, as if the place itself were hungry for broken bodies. The manager knew this. Knew it like he knew his own name. Sat there anyway eating while danger waited in his aisles like some hungry god.

They would argue now in courts of law whether his actions rose to the level of despicable, whether his disregard for the safety of others was willful and conscious. As if such things could be measured and weighed like produce in his store. But the truth was there in the cold facts: twice warned and twice he chose his dinner over the safety of others. The law would find its way to justice because that's what laws do, grinding slow but grinding fine, turning facts into verdicts like grain into meal.

The wanting lived in her like a half-starved thing. It commenced round about her fourteenth year and wouldnt leave her be, not then and not now at seventeen neither. Time had shown her it wasnt objects she craved but something more vital. Yet the boys who came calling stirred nothing in her heart. They would make their clumsy advances like wandering pilgrims seeking salvation but finding only empty churches. She pondered this peculiarity deep into the night hours, searching for some truth in the darkness of her own mind but finding no answers that satisfied.

The house she dwelt in was mostly peaceful. Her folks carried a quietness about them like old leather worn smooth, never raising voices against one another and seldom against their daughter save for when she tested the bounds of her freedom. She was wild energy contained in young flesh, carrying herself with a brightness that drew others to her like moths to flame yet harboring kindness beneath it all.

But peace aint a permanent state in this world. She was walking the rooms seeking something she couldn't name when her mothers scream tore through the quiet like a knife. It was a sound that carried pain and fear wrapped together in one terrible note. She found her mother splayed on the kitchen floor, each breath carrying small sounds of agony like wind through dying leaves. Hospital, the mother managed through gritted teeth. The girl gathered her up like something precious and broken, thankful for the strength in her arms that the iron had given her. She laid her mother across the backseat of the car like a funeral offering and drove.

The hospital carried its own particular perfume of death and cleanliness but she noticed none of it, her mind fixed only on the woman who bore her. She carried her burden through those sterile halls calling out like some ancient herald announcing tragedy. White-coated figures materialized from the fluorescent gloom, whisking her mother away on wheels while she stood abandoned to worry and wait.

All this because of a vase perched too high and a stepstool that proved treacherous.

They sought truth in numbers and blood. The Mediterranean way of eating, ancient as the stones themselves, whispered promises of longer life through the statistics. Not some simple thing but a dance of olive oil and fish, of grain and fruit born from sun-scorched earth. No potatoes. The flesh of beasts used sparingly. Wine in moderation, like the old ones knew.

Before them others had walked this path. Studies spoke of hearts beating longer, of death's shadow falling later for those who followed the old ways. The fat-fearing prophets had been wrong. Their low-fat gospel crumbled like dust while the Mediterranean truth endured, especially among the heavy of flesh.

They watched the nurses. Seventy-four thousand eight hundred and eighty-six women, each carrying her own history of health and hurt, none touched yet by the sugar sickness or the heart's betrayal. From eleven states they came, marking their food on papers six times across twenty years, faithful as pilgrims. Most stayed true to the end.

The counters of numbers verified everything. When death came they checked the records, the certificates, the cold facts of autopsy. Some deaths they called probable when papers failed them, ghostly statistics haunting the margins of truth. They measured the women's flesh, their smoke habits, the pills they took, the bleeding of their bodies, the movement of their limbs in leisure.

They built models from numbers, complex as cathedral windows, adjusting for the confusion of facts that plague all seeking of truth. Age and smoke and flesh and movement, all accounted for in their equations.

In the end the numbers spoke clear as blood on sand. Those who followed the old ways, who ate as their Mediterranean ancestors ate, they lived longer. Their hearts stayed stronger. Their blood flowed true through unthreatened channels. Two thousand three hundred ninety-one hearts failed. One thousand seven hundred sixty-three minds lost their rivers of blood. One thousand seventy-seven returned to dust from these causes combined. But those who ate true to the old ways, they endured. Their risk fell like autumn leaves, scattered by winds of statistical significance.

Hitler lives, the sign read. Just that and nothing more.

The girl stood at the corner holding cardboard above her head like some prophet of old, dark letters bleeding into the fiber. Burma they call it now. Myanmar too. Names dont matter much when blood runs in gutters. The junta came in 62 and they came with guns and tanks and the old order fell like dead leaves in autumn. Aint nothing new under the sun.

They marched in 2007, them monks in robes color of dying sun. Saffron they called it. First time anyone dared march in ten years and the monks led them like Christ leading lambs. Military let them be at first but violence has its own rhythm, its own heartbeat. Soon enough the guns came out and the monasteries burned. They hunted journalists like coyotes hunt rabbits. Shot that Japanese man Nagai dead in the street for nothing more than holding a camera. Official count says thirteen dead but the colonel who run off told different. Bodies in the thousands he said. Just numbers now. Numbers dont mean nothing to the dead.

Been that way since men first gathered in tribes. Roman emperors claimed divine right same as Japanese ones did. Same as all tyrants do. Even now they wave their papers and hold their meetings, talking to god on golden telephone lines, telling the people what the lord wants. Aint nothing changed since Caesars time.

Square in China filled with students and workers in 89. Tank tracks on concrete and blood mixing with rain. Government says few hundred. Red Cross says thousands. Rwanda saw neighbors killing neighbors, machetes in the dawn light. Hitler and his reich burning people like cordwood. World keeps turning. Sun rises on the dead same as the living.

The girl stands there still with her sign. Words dont change nothing but still she stands. Sometimes standing is all we got left.

They say Duke Ellington carried jazz in his bones and the weight of that music bore down through the years like some ancient thing passed from father to son in the dark of night. His fingers moved across ivory keys quiet as windblown snow while the compositions he birthed came forth like fever dreams, rich and strange and filled with the voices of men who'd signed their souls to his orchestra. Each piece a framework built of notes and carried on the wind, and within that framework men could dance their solos wild and free or march in lockstep precise as soldiers to war.

The way he wrote was like a man who knew the hearts of his players better than they knew themselves. Each note crafted special for the particular demon that lived in their horns, in their fingers, in their breath. The sound would rise up whole and pure like something torn from the earth itself.

They wrote of him in Grove, them scholars of sound, speaking of Creole Love Call like witnesses to some strange ceremony. Voice become instrument, wordless and pure. The piece moved like this: First the voice crying out smooth as silk then turning rough as gravel, the reeds answering back like lost souls. Then came the trumpet, muted and blue as midnight, followed by clarinet sailing high above like some night bird. The whole band rose up then, brass and reed calling back and forth like wolves in darkness. At the height of it all the reeds screamed high and wild while brass and rhythm punched holes in time itself. Then back to voice and reed once more, the voice growling like some trapped thing, before it all ended in dissonance and darkness.

A year later came Hot and Bothered, Miley's muted trumpet crying out to Baby Cox's voice, instrument and human throat tangled together like lovers. Later still It Don't Mean a Thing rose up with Nanton's trombone leading the way like some twisted prophet. The sound of it all carrying forward through time like echoes in a cave, bearing witness to what jazz was and what it could become.

They say evolution moves like a river but that aint right. It moves like blood in the veins of some ancient thing, coursing through time without memory or purpose. In 1917 Thompson wrote that we hadnt even begun to speak of living things in numbers and equations and maybe we still aint. The truth of it lies somewhere in the bones of things, in the slow accretion of shell and matter, in the geometric prophecies written in calcium and time.

We took to studying these shells called Prunum, their shapes like God's own mathematics spiraling out into darkness. The xray images showed their ghostly forms like photographs of souls departing. We fed these numbers into machines, made digital phantoms of what could be, what might have been. The boundaries of possibility written in code.

A shell aint nothing but a tube moving through space like some cosmic dance, turning round and round in degrees measured by men who think numbers can capture the essence of things. These turns we call whorls like the whorls of a fingerprint left by creation itself. They spiral round a center that aint there, a columella, holy and empty as a church at midnight. The last whorl always the biggest like the final word in some argument with time itself.

You can hold these shells and turn them any way you want. Apical, basal, apertural. Words we made up to pretend we understand. But the truth is in the counting of the whorls, in drawing lines across their faces like reading the age rings of trees or the marks on a prisoner's wall. Each shell nothing but a series of doors opening into time, each aperture a moment frozen in calcium carbonate, each mathematical coordinate a point on some map leading nowhere and everywhere at once.

And when we write these things down in numbers and equations we aint really capturing the thing itself but just its shadow on the cave wall of our understanding. The mathematics of it all just another way of trying to speak the language of whatever god or devil designed such geometries.

They watched the numbers like dark harbingers, unchanging and merciless across the Indonesian archipelago. Ten years gone and the dead infants still came, regular as the tides, while mothers lay bleeding in bamboo huts and concrete hospitals alike. Progress marched in some quarters - water flowing clean now where once it ran thick with death, but the children and their bearers paid their toll all the same, numbers scratched in ledgers far from the birthing rooms where life and death played their ancient game.

Midwives came more frequent now, seven of ten births seeing their weathered hands, but they stood powerless before the complications that turned routine delivery to tragedy. Blood flowing unchecked, staining dirt floors and sterile sheets without distinction. The numbers told lies of improvement while truth lay in the graves.

In the cities they cut mothers open when needed, steel against flesh, seven percent saved this way. But in the villages only two in hundred felt the knife's mercy. The division lay stark as lightning against a black sky - wealth and poverty, city and countryside, each marking their territories in infant breaths and mother's tears. Twenty-seven percent separated rich from poor in who lived and who died, coin and paper determining fate as surely as any god.

They argued in offices about solutions, program-specific approaches versus systemic change, while blood continued flowing and babies drew their last breaths. Vertical approaches promised quick victories, neat columns of improvement in official reports. But such solutions carried their own poison, drawing resources like vultures to fresh kill, leaving other needs to wither and die. They'd seen it before - AIDS programs swallowing family planning whole, duplicate services sprouting like weeds after rain, paperwork multiplying like some bureaucratic plague. All while mothers waited, and babies died, and the numbers remained unchanging as stone.

The thing about Popular Music aint that it grew or changed but that it mutated like some dark creature beneath the earth, spreading its tendrils through a hundred years of human suffering and joy until there wasnt no way to count its manifestations anymore. You got your rap and your rock and your country and jazz and folk music but they aint pure no more, each one spawning bastard children of their own kind, darker and stranger with each passing generation.

Heavy Metal came crawling out of this darkness some forty years past and it grew teeth. It grew claws. It showed mankind what music could be when you fed it raw meat and gunpowder, when you let it loose in the night to hunt. They say its expressive but what it expresses aint the kind of things decent folk want expressed. It deals in shadow and blood and the places where God dont look no more.

These days you cant hardly tell what Metal is anymore. Like some shapeshifter in them old stories it takes whatever form suits it, borrowing pieces of other music like a crow stealing bright things for its nest. To know Metal you got to know where it came from, got to understand that it aint just music but something that moves through the world like a fever through the blood.

Metal lives in the dark places. It demands more of everything - more noise more violence more skill with the instruments that make its unholy sounds. Them that play it aint amateurs but dark priests of their craft. Back in the seventies when the drugs came flooding in like a biblical plague the music got stranger still, like it was speaking in tongues nobody was meant to understand. They made records that sounded like messages from some other world, a world where the sun never rises and everything beautiful is broken. Even them Beatles, them nice boys from Liverpool, they got touched by it. Helter Skelter they called it, like they was naming some demon they'd conjured up, trying to outdo them Stones in darkness and weight.

In the years before the dreamers took to their canvases with their strange visions the man Rousseau had already begun to paint his own. The dreams came to him like thieves in the night and he put them down with careful strokes as if marking the passage of time itself. The painting called The Dream came in 1910 and in it lay not just some woman caught in the spell of strange lands but the very essence of Rousseau's own yearnings that had haunted him through the years. Recognition. Acceptance. Praise. These things moved through his mind like wraiths and led him down paths that forked and split until he knew not which way to turn.

He was born to a tinsmith in Laval where the spring rains fell hard on the slate roofs and the streets ran wet with the tears of commerce. No teacher showed him the ways of art and color and light. Instead he walked the cobbled streets as a gabelou collecting coins from the carts and wagons that passed through the gates of the city while the years spun past like leaves in autumn wind. Death came for his children. Eight small souls claimed before their time. Then it took his Clémence and left him with only Julia and the vast emptiness that follows such losses. He turned to painting like a man turns to drink, seeking solace in the colors and shapes that flowed from his brush.

The art world was not kind to such men as he. While others who had learned their craft in schools and academies gained fame and fortune he remained in shadows. Matisse had already begun to make his name when Rousseau finally found some small measure of recognition. They were as different as earth and sky these two. Matisse painted with fury against convention while Rousseau sought only to be embraced by it. Like a child seeking approval from stern parents he painted and waited and hoped while the critics passed him by with scarce a glance.

The common folk saw themselves in his work though he never meant it so. He painted what he saw in dreams and memories while others painted peasants with romantic eyes. His was the art of truth though none could see it then. The truth of a man who carried his dreams like stones in his pockets, weighing him down even as they gave him purpose.

They'd spoken of it before, these men of letters, how truth and beauty walked the same path like brothers in the desert night. Not separate things but one thing, moving through time like a snake through sand leaving only the faintest trace of its passing. Keats knew it when he wrote of that ancient urn, speaking truth to beauty and beauty to truth, and that was all there was and all there needed to be.

The things we know come to us through books and time and the hard lessons of years, but this knowing of beauty and right action comes unbidden like rain in August. We don't learn it. It's already there waiting to be found like old bones in the earth. When we speak of these things we ain't prescribing nothing. We're just trying to describe what's already there, been there since before any of us drew breath.

You can talk about the Mona Lisa all day long. Talk about her smile and them mountains behind her and what Leonardo was thinking when he painted her. But that ain't it. That ain't never been it. People stand before her and they say there's just something about her and that something is the truth of it. Same with what's right and wrong. You can write all the books you want about it but you ain't never gonna capture it complete. O'Connor knew it. Said a story was the only way to say the things that couldn't be said no other way. Like trying to describe the wind. You can talk about what it moves and what it destroys but you ain't never gonna catch it in your hands.

The truth of it is that beauty and morality are like two horses running the same trail in the dark. You can't see em proper but you know they're there. You feel em in your bones like thunder. Kant called it noumenal. Something you could know but never explain. Like how a man knows right from wrong before he ever learns the words for either. The writers know it best. They know that words on paper ain't just about making pretty sounds. They're about showing us what's true and what's right, even if we can't say exactly why. That's what makes em matter. That's what makes em real.

The Germany that stands now rises like some ancient colossus from the earth itself, a thing wrought from blood and iron and time immemorial. From the shadow-haunted peaks of München where the alps rear against god's own sky down to where Kiel's dark waters lap at shores older than memory. The land speaks its own tongue from Köln where the Rhine cuts deep through history to Dresden squatting like some Saxon sentinel on the Elbe's banks. This place, this Germany, it carries in its soil the bones of a thousand tribes, each one leaving its mark like brands upon cattle.

Germania they called it, those ancient ones who first put name to this wild place. The scholars and learned men they argue still about what that name means, their words falling like dead leaves in autumn winds. Tacitus, that Roman who wrote of savage lands, he said the name came from the Tungrians, fierce warriors who crossed the Rhine and fought the Gauls until their blood ran into the earth. Caesar too, he spoke of these Germans, wrote of them in his accounts of war and conquest. He took the word from Gaulish tongues, marking those he'd beaten from those who stood yet unconquered. Some say it meant neighbor in that old speech, others claim it spoke of their spears, those terrible gers that drank deep of Roman blood, or maybe it came from their battle cries that echoed through forests primeval.

Tacitus wrote more, in that year ninety-eight after their Christ, speaking of these Germans as if they'd sprung full-formed from the black soil itself. No mixing of blood, he said, no wanderers come seeking better lands. For who would choose such a place, he asked, with its wild woods and bitter skies, unless it was already carved into their very bones?

And indeed what Roman would venture here save by order or madness? They came for plunder and glory, leading their legions through trackless woods, but always they returned to their marble cities and warm wines. The Germans, they lived there in the shadows of empire, trading what the land gave up and selling their strength to Rome's armies, their blood mixing with the soil that would one day bear their name.

The stage holds truth and lies both, and in Twelfth Night they dance together like snakes in the dust, writhing and coiling until you cant tell where one ends and the other begins. The masks we wear they protect us yes but they eat at the soul like acid on metal and in time there aint nothing left of what you were before. Some folk they take kind to learning theyve been fooled but others theyll cut you deep for such betrayal and there aint no going back from that kind of wound.

When a woman puts on mans clothes its like staring into a dark mirror that shows all manner of uncomfortable truths. Viola she done what she had to do, surviving like a wounded animal in strange territory. The captain helped her yes, gave her mens clothes like armor against the world that would tear her apart otherwise. But armor weighs heavy and in time it leaves marks that dont heal.

She walked among them like a ghost between worlds. The women they turned from her not knowing she was their kind and Olivia god help her she fell into loving what wasnt there to love at all. Husband she called her, that word hanging in the air like gunsmoke. And Orsino he spoke of love too, words spilling out like blood from an old wound, telling this boy-that-wasnt how no woman could match such devotion.

There's them that might say Shakespeare was showing us something about the nature of want and desire, how it lives in dark places we dont care to look at. Olivia seeing what she wanted to see, loving a shadow of a thing that never was. Maybe she loved the woman beneath them boys clothes or maybe she just loved the lie of it all. But when Sebastian come along looking like the ghost of that lie made flesh she took to him quick as a rattler strikes, and Viola became sister instead of lover, the way the world rights itself after a storm.

They spoke of the German rule in those lands and how it carried a darkness with it, a darkness that found its fullest expression in the killing of the Ovaherero and the Nama people. But empires aint simple things and cant be marked by single deeds no matter how terrible. The Germans ruled different in different places and they ruled according to the land and according to what they thought of the people who lived there.

In the eastern territories they built schools and taught the natives to read and when the British came in 1919 they found africans who could write their names in perfect german script. But in the southwest territories it wasnt like that at all. No it wasnt like that at all.

The southwest was different. There the government gave the teaching of natives over to the missionaries who worked with what little they were given while the white children went to fine schools built with government money. These things dont die. They go on and on through the years like a curse laid upon the land. While other colonies had natives who could read books and write letters the southwest stayed in darkness. Ignorant. Unable to read the words that condemned them.

The old books tell what happened. Most written in german and yellowed now with age. They tell how things were different in different places but they dont tell why. Later books written in english tried to explain it. A man named Cohen wrote on it. He said it was the settlers that made it different. More of them in the southwest than anywhere else in the german colonies.

The southwest was good country for whites. Not too hot. Desert yes but a desert a white man could live in. By 1913 there were fifteen thousand of them there. In the east where it was hotter and the land was different there wasnt but five thousand. The whites in the southwest they wanted things a certain way. They got what they wanted.

They stood there the two nations like ancient enemies across a dried riverbed of time and blood. Fifty-seven years they warred and feuded, from eighteen thirty-six until eighteen ninety-three, the high water mark being that war of forty-six where American boys marched south and took what wasnt theirs to take. Texas and the lands beyond. Sacred ground stained with the blood of generations. The people different as night and day, their gods different too.

The world is full of such neighbors. Full of such feuds. Nations that share borders share bloodshed like communion wine. Mexico and these United States aint special in that regard. Only Mexico and Cuba, someone once wrote, only they caused such lasting trouble for the American dream. Both of them close enough to touch. Close enough to hate.

Religion ran deep like a poison well between them. Where Americans feared the papal crown and catholic cross in them days like they'd later fear the communist star, inheriting old hatreds from across the sea where English and Spanish had warred before them. Ancient grudges passed down like family heirlooms, poisoning any chance of peace.

Seventeen times they clashed proper in them fifty-seven years. Most times over land and borders where outlaws and murderers crossed back and forth like desert wolves, preying on both sides until both nations sent their armies to hunt them down. The armies met too sometimes, these encounters writ in blood across the dusty pages of history.

In the end it wasnt peace that stopped the killing but money. Mexico grew dependent on American coin like a man grows dependent on water in the desert. The United States no longer hungered for land but for profit, and slowly the old wounds scabbed over though they never truly healed. Some say they never will.

Fifteen years back the sickness came. Not gradual like most afflictions but sudden and complete, a thief in the night stealing what was mine to keep. I didn't even know such a malady existed in this world.

I wore white then. Moved through antiseptic halls ministering to the sick and dying. Chose that path from some deep-seated need for sanctuary, the kind that eluded me in youth. They'd say: Work will always find you, for the sick walk among us eternal. So I buried my dreams of science and words and took up the mantle of healing.

Then there I stood. Forty-six winters gone, alone, coffers empty as a desert well, unable to labor. Still am. Fifteen years living off government scraps has stripped me bare of possessions and pride alike. Each dawn brings its own war against security and worth. Nothing certain now save uncertainty itself. Yet this truth remains: survival came not from personal fortitude but through the mercy of blood kin and true friends. When calamity visits, it takes all strength just to breathe.

Life brings its catastrophes, big and small as grains of sand. No guarantees in this world. No preparation sufficient against its largest storms. We cant weather them alone.

True enough we need less faith in government's rotting basket. But better to learn trust in our fellow man than to dig individual holes in the earth like scared rabbits. They speak of rugged individualism building this nation but that aint the truth of it. What carried our ancestors through was mercy and mutual aid and the sharing of what little they had. Them pioneer wagons didnt cross the mountains one by one.

Be ready, yes. Keep your emergency stores. Your medical supplies and water tablets and window coverings against whatever poison might come floating on the wind. Keep your lights and batteries and matches sealed against the wet. Store food if you can. Plant if you got earth to plant in. Heat with wood if walls allow.

But know your neighbor too. For in the end that's all we got.

In the old world, in times before memory, a prince drew breath who would come to be known as Buddha. He walked away from all he knew into darkness and returned with light in his eyes. His words spread like fire through dry grass and from them grew Buddhism, its purest form called Theravada. Twenty-five hundred years have passed and time has worked its violence upon the teachings as it does upon all things. In Sri Lanka they cut water now in ceremony, monks and common folk alike moving through rituals Buddha never spoke of, never dreamed. The changes run deeper than mere ceremony. They run to the bone and marrow of what salvation means.

The words we use matter. Internal and external like the inside and outside of a skull. Internal being those who walk the Buddha's path, external being those who dont. Some forces come with knives drawn, meaning harm. Others pass by like storms that neither know nor care what stands in their path but may still tear down temples or plant seeds in their passing. These words will walk with us through what follows.

The heart of it beats thus: Three jewels they call them. Buddha. Dhamma. Sangha. The Dhamma held in three vessels, three baskets of words passed down. The Suttas speak of teachings. The Vinaya speaks of rules. The Abhidhamma speaks of what lies beyond the world we know. They tell of how no soul exists eternal, how suffering dogs all life like a shadow, how nothing lasts. Know these things and you might break free from the wheel that turns life into death into life again. Break free from want and hate and the fog that clouds mens minds. The Vinaya sets down the law. For common folk five rules: kill nothing, speak true, take nothing not given, keep the flesh holy, shun the spirits that cloud the mind. For monks the rules run deeper, darker. But at the core lie four truths simple as stones: Life is suffering. Want breeds suffering. Suffering can end. These truths carve the path through darkness.

Culture plays a significant role in any negotiation. Culture can be defined as much by what it is not as what it actually is and what it signifies. Culture is not homogenous, nor is it a specific thing. It is also not singular or uniform. Statements such as “all Russians are stubborn” or “all Japanese are accommodating,” are inherently broad and overly simplistic. While the understanding of a culture’s generalizations are appropriate, it is much more productive to a negotiator to understand the significance of a culture to the matter at hand, and how that culture’s attitude can and will affect the table talks. When one approaches a foreign culture, one experiences it in a way that is relatable to his own culture, and comparisons necessarily arise. 

Attempting to understand a foreign culture or mindset can involve anything from studying its history to realizing its prejudices. Rather than judging or attempting to change a culture, one must simply accept it for what it is, and work within its boundaries, especially within the scope of negotiation, and most especially if one comes to the table with a weaker bargaining position. Likewise, if a negotiator finds himself on “away” territory, a respect for traditions and beliefs can only help in getting over any cultural barriers and move the negotiation forward.

It is important to note that culture does not necessarily limit itself to a national/international dichotomy. Most companies within a given nation establish their own corporate culture. For instance, a corporate culture might emphasize long hours in the office or a more relaxed schedule. Evidence of a corporate culture can be seen in employee dress codes, in communication style (direct v. indirect communication, delegation of duties), and hiring practices. Some companies encourage philanthropy at any level from employees, others restrict it to “company approved” charities or fundraisers. One need only look at the differences in American corporate culture from company to company (and indeed, intra-company diversity exists even from region to region, urban to suburban environments included) to appreciate the diversity of thought that can reside within a particular societal culture. Certain cultures are not nearly as stratified as American culture, and may appear more uniform to an outsider, but a similar exterior is simply a sign to dig deeper. 

Values are even more important to understand, because they provide the why of a culture. If saving face or communal harmony are valued within a culture, it is certain that a negotiator will not publicly shame his company or his superior in order to succeed at the negotiation table. Likewise, a negotiator from a culture which gives greater weight to a hard-driven bargain will not necessarily be driven to settle at the earliest opportunity. Taking these generalities into consideration is important before one gets to the negotiating table. However, a negotiator is well-served to learn something about his opponent on a personal level in order to make the negotiation effective.

“The fool hath said in his heart, ‘There is no God.’” The preceding quotation is seen first in Psalm 14 of the Christian Bible, and is found at the beginning of St. Anselm’s argument regarding the existence of God. This belief seems to also be held by the other author whom we will be discussing, Thomas Aquinas. Because each of their arguments is in defense of the same concept, and our challenge is to determine who’s is the better of the two, we must, for sake of brevity, begin with the presumption that they are both correct in their belief in the existence of God, specifically the God of the Bible. To allow for a God-type figure that may not resemble the one in whom our two authors believe would not permit us to appropriately compare their two arguments, as they are essentially in defense of one specific concept of God. That being said, I would suggest that while each of them brings up valid points, neither truly provides a holistic basis for belief in God.
	To illustrate this point, we will first examine the basic argument of St. Anselm. Anselm’s passage reflects a path of gaining understanding through faith, looking within one’s self to find proof of God. He explains that because God exists within our understanding, we cannot effectively conceive his nonexistence. While this concept, when spelled out in his terminology, is a bit tedious and at times unclear, the basic gist of it is that the proof for God lies within one’s own mind. St. Anselm is suggesting to us that we needn’t go beyond the confines of our own soul to find truth about God, but that the existence of this being is found to be true simply by examining that which we inherently know to be true within our own minds. Foreign evidence is presumably unnecessary. This concept of accepting that for which there is not an irrefutable body of empirical evidence is often referred to within Christian texts as faith.
	This idea is very different from that held by St. Thomas Aquinas. Aquinas instead suggests that the existence of God can be proven entirely through reason and empirical evidence, with no need for faith of any kind. Such an idea would be beneficial in evangelism, an important element of Christianity, because it would enable the recruiting of new converts without any dependency upon their willingness to accept something that cannot be proven. They could instead be persuaded by logic alone. St. Thomas elaborates on five different logical arguments supporting the existence of God: change, causation, contingency, degrees of excellence, and harmony. In each he essentially demonstrates that the proof of God lies in the logical necessity for God. If you are told that that you are missing one puzzle piece, and assemble the rest of the puzzle, logic dictates that you can know of the features and the existence of the missing piece without having to see it.

Many authors use different ways to give their readers a certain feeling or attitude toward
important subjects. Some of these techniques are more effective than others. F. Scott Fitzgerald uses
many of these different techniques in his novel The Great Gatsby. Sometimes, Fitzgerald pairs an
adjective and a noun together that do not usually fit that way to give readers a certain aura around a
subject. Other times, he applies meaning to a symbol, and then uses it for this same purpose.
Fitzgerald uses this last technique with many colors, including gold, green, white/gray and red/pink. In
his novel The Great Gatsby F. Scott Fitzgerald builds up meaning for colors, namely white/gray and
red/pink then later uses that meaning to give readers a certain reminder of a feeling around an
important object.
The meaning Fitzgerald builds up and uses for white/gray is uniformity, with white being a bit
nicer and higher class and gray being more older and faded. Fitzgerald sets up this meaning in the
beginning of the novel with constant uses of both. Daisy and Jordan are constantly “in white” (8)—in
fact, everyone is always wearing white: Nick wears “white flannels” (41) to Gatsby’s party, Tom wears
a “white shirt” (36) when he meets Myrtle, and Catherine is “powdered milky white” (30). In fact, the
only time people are not wearing white is when Nick is getting his impressions of Gatsby’s party: “the
halls... are gaudy with primary colors” (40). Fitzgerald further defines these two colors in coloring
many common, unimportant subjects these colors: as Nick goes to work, he goes “down the white
chasms of lower New York” (56), the names of people at Gatsby’s parties are now “gray names” (61)
on Nick’s timetable, Catherine’s apartment is “one slice in a long white cake of apartment-houses”—
uniformity (28). He also describes plain or common people or places as white or gray: Jordan and
Daisy had a “white girlhood” (19) together, there are “gray cars” and “gray land” (23) in the valley of
ashes, the “Italian child” in the railroad is “gray” (26), and the dog-seller is “a gray old man” (27).
After Fitzgerald adds enough meaning to white/gray, he uses them to signify unimportance or
uniformity to certain subjects. This using colors to show readers something first starts with Daisy.
After a long time without any significant use of either of these colors, Fitzgerald comes out describing
Daisy as “dressed in white” in “a little white roadster”; readers begin to see Daisy as less of a character,
more like just a uniform addition, something that Gatsby wants and longs for (74). Fitzgerald uses
more of this technique around Daisy to give this impression of Daisy being a more uniform addition,
for example, there is a “gray haze of Daisy’s fur collar” (18), and she is again in a “white” (115) dress
before Tom and Gatsby’s encounter.

San Diego County is very agriculturally productive, thanks to a mild, sunny climate. Common crops include: tomatoes, citrus, leafy greens, squash, broccoli, herbs, tree fruits like peaches and lemons, berries, honey, and peppers. There is a substantial market for organic community supported agriculture food in the San Diego area, with many local organizations having lengthy waiting lists. Organic eggs and milk are also popular. Many organic farms also provide tours of their agricultural operations as well as access for hiking, birdwatching, and other recreational activities. This is the type of operation that would allow the landowner to gain the benefits of government programs while improving habitat, thus allowing recreational use and creating an opportunity for farm tours and other programs for making money or for educational purposes.  
	In addition to filling a potentially lucrative niche market, the benefits of organic farming often include greater biodiversity in plants and wildlife in the area thanks to a lack of chemicals in the soil and water. However, organic farming has greater costs than conventional farming in some ways. It requires more intensive labor and management to remove pests and weeds and fertilize the soil without chemicals, and losses are often greater than with conventional methods, while a small organic farm also lacks the efficiency of scale of large operations. Practices not related to organic farming but beneficial to wildlife may also incur greater labor costs, including planting cover crops, strategic grazing rotation, invasive species removal, and active management of plant growth to provide specific conditions such as edge habitat or patches of open ground. Thus, there are many reasons why the landowner in this example might seek financial help or expertise in maximizing both profits and habitat quality.  
The land chosen for this scenario is a parcel adjacent to the town of Potrero, in unincorporated San Diego County, California. It is 160 acres of chaparral, nonnative Mediterranean grassland, and oak woodland next to to the Cleveland National Forest. It lies in the East County Southern Foothills ecoregion of the San Diego Multiple Species Conservation Plan. The plan is still being reviewed, but presently considers over a hundred species of plants and animals. Many are endangered, such as the Stephens' kangaroo rat, the mountain yellow-legged frog, several species of butterfly, and the California gnatcatcher; others are declining and may soon be listed, such as burrowing owls.
	This area was inhabited by Native Americans for untold centuries and was then settled by cattle ranchers and cordwood sellers in the late 1800's. This piece of land was part of an original homestead patent and so was probably used for grazing and/or wood production for many of the intervening decades.
	 chose a piece of property from a real estate website and researched available government programs to see what options a small farmer might realistically have for mitigating costs and preserving wildlife-friendly operations.  As a model of what somebody farming this land might attempt to achieve, I located an organic farm in the same area.

There is a bond between brothers; an unbreakable, irrevocable bond. Within that bond lie many emotions: love, pride, jealousy, and cruelty, just to name a few. Brothers understand one another, far more than anyone else with that kind of bond, and they can only see themselves when looking at their brother. It is when a situation is at its most dire when the true nature of this bond shines through, be it good or evil. When these emotions become clear, they carry with them great a cost. Part of understanding the emotions born of this fraternal link is dealing with the consequences that they bring. When one can look a brother in the eye and see within that person their own reflection, they see themselves not as others see them, but as they truly are. In their actions and the consequences of those actions is where their true character lies.  In “The Scarlet Ibis”, two brothers explore this theme, and all of the raging emotions that accompany it. Throughout a lush, vividly described landscape, these two boys set out on a futile journey. Bitter disappointment clashes with intense pride in the climactic scene, and only one brother escapes with his life. The theme is expressed through direct characterization of the protagonist, Doodle, and their interactions with each other, as well as through the narrator’s point of view, which communicates the complex feelings experienced by the protagonist and his view of the world around him, both of which are heavy influences on his actions.
	The protagonist’s actions can all be summed up by one key emotion: pride. From the time he and his little brother, Doodle, first go out together, to their final, fateful excursion, the protagonist feels resentment towards Doodle. He had wanted a brother whom he could teach all of his worldly skills, like “…holding my breath, running, jumping, or climbing the vines in Old Woman Swamp…” He wanted a brother who could fill the role of “…someone to race to Horsehead Landing…and someone to perch with in the top fork of the great pine behind the barn…” Obviously these things are impossible, given Doodle’s condition. Doodle was born with an extremely weak heart, making in unlikely he would even survive. Even then, it was nearly impossible that he would ever participate in vigorous physical activity. What a blow to the young protagonist, his head filled with wild fantasies, to have all of those dreams crushed in an instant. In fact, he is even shown to bear some anger towards the small child, as he recalls beginning to contemplate killing him by suffocating him with a pillow. What kind of child would have the presence of mind to consider infanticide? However, his heart melts when the small child smiles at him. Such a simple act gave the protagonist such hope! This shows that his conviction probably was not very strong. In the back of his mind, he had an instinctive love for his brother.

The human brain is a complicated, creative information-processing system. As technology advanced from primitive to modern, the metaphors used to describe the brain also advanced. Initially, it was compared to a wax tablet, then to a sheet of papyrus, then to a book, and most recently, to a computer. As you learn about the brain, keep in mind that the usefulness of these metaphors is limited and can lead to erroneous conclusions.
Information processing starts with input from the sensory organs, which transform physical stimuli such as touch, heat, sound waves, or photons of light into electrochemical signals. The sensory information is repeatedly transformed by the algorithms of the brain in both bottom-up and top-down processing. For example, when looking at a picture of a black box on a white background, bottom-up processing puts together very simple information such as color, orientation, and where the borders of the object are – where the color changes significantly over a short space – to decide that you are seeing a box. Top-down processing uses the decisions made at some steps of the bottom-up process to speed up your recognition of the box. Top-down processing in this example might help you identify the object as a black box rather than a box-shaped hole in the white background.
Once information is processed to a degree, an attention filter decides how important the signal is and which cognitive processes it should be made available to. For example, although your brain processes every blade of grass when you look down at your shoes, a healthy attention filter prevents you from noticing them individually. In contrast, you might pick out your name, even when spoken in a noisy room. There are many stages of processing, and the results of processing are modulated by attention repeatedly.
