The death toll in that particular instance ranges wildly, with official reports from the Chinese government stating 200-300 dead to reports let out by the Chinese Red Cross, declaring between 2,000-3,000 dead.  Another is the Rwandan genocide of the 1990s, where Hutu militia groups, aided by the Rwandan government, began a systematic killing of all Tutsis, as well as political moderates, irrespective of their ethnic backgrounds. Hitler’s ‘Third Reich’, a period spanning several years and several countries where anyone of Jewish background was rounded up and killed, is another extreme example.

Duke Ellington’s legacy in jazz derives in large part from his longevity and, by extension, his creative abilities to shape his orchestra. Ellington’s presence on the piano is subtle in many of the compositions selected for this assignment, but as a composer Ellington excelled at creating rich and complex pieces that showcased the individual abilities of band members. Ellington crafted the framework in which a soloist could freely improvise, in addition to writing tightly orchestrated pieces and phrases that called on the particular style of band members to highlight musical ideas. In doing this, he also emphasized the tone of the orchestra more generally, creating coherent and original sounds to fit each piece. Ellington’s mastery of the individual players’ sound, as well as how they fit together in a growing ensemble, enabled him to write some of the most innovative and brilliant pieces in jazz history.
The Grove Music dictionary, in discussing Ellington’s sound and innovation, mentions Creole Love Call in reference to using voice “as a jazz instrument” throughout his career.  This is an early example of Ellington’s use of voice to add texture and color without the hindrance of lyrics. Creole Love Call also demonstrates Ellington’s ability to compliment the style of his soloists, something that is evident throughout his career. This slow, deliberate twelve bar blues piece contains six choruses, as follows:
Chorus 1: Call and response between voice and reeds, where the voice begins smooth and melodic, then transitions to a rougher sound towards the end.
Chorus 2: Muted trumpet solo that elaborates on the basic melody and emphasizes several extended blue notes.
Chorus 3: Sweeping clarinet solo in a high register, backed by a subtle syncopated piano phrase.
Chorus 4: Full band echoes the first chorus with a call and response by the brass and reed sections.
Chorus 5: The climactic chorus of the piece, as the reeds now begin the call and response in a high register, backed by syncopated stop time from the brass and rhythm sections.
Chorus 6: A return to the structure of the first chorus, with call and response between voice and reeds. In this chorus the voice takes on the sound of the “growl” technique, soloing as an instrument.
Tag: Brief tag featuring a vocal run and a dissonant novelty ending by a trombone.
Ellington’s use of voice to add a dimension of tone color to this piece is one example of a stylistic trait that permeates his work. 
In Hot and Bothered, recorded a year later, Ellington combines his skill at tight orchestration with his ear for tone color. A call and response phrase between “Bubber” Miley on muted trumpet and Baby Cox’s scat singing uses the vocal elements of Miley’s playing and instrumental aspects of Cox’s voice to create a rich and complementary sound. It Don’t Mean a Thing (If It Ain’t Got That Swing) extends these ideas, as Ellington uses Joe “Tricky Sam” Nanton, a mainstay in Ellington’s orchestra, to great effect in introducing the melody on muted trombone.

Why do organisms evolve in the manner that they do‭? ‬Are there restrictions or constraints that influence the direction of evolutionary change‭? ‬Although in‭ ‬1917‭ ‬D’Arcy Thompson stated that‭ “‬Even now the zoologist has scarce begun to dream of defining in mathematical language even the simplest organic forms‭” ‬the same can be said today. More recently,‭ ‬mathematical modeling has been applied to general aspects of mollusk skeletogenesis through both ontogeny and phylogeny‭ (‬e.g.,‭ ‬Raup and Stanley,‭ ‬1981‭)‬. Our study is exploring how mathematical modeling of ontogenetic and phylogenetic change in Prunum,‭ ‬in combination with experimental studies,‭ ‬can be used to elucidate the mechanisms involved in the direction and magnitude of evolutionary-developmental change. We used X-radiographic images of Prunum species to delineate quantitative parameters that could in turn be used to model hypothetical and actual skeletal morphologies. These parameters were entered into the software program CerioShell‭ (‬Stone,‭ ‬1995‭)‬. We modeled hypothetical shell morphologies that could be used to interpret the boundaries of possible morphological change in Prunum. These results are being combined with experimental and descriptive studies in order to better understand macroevolutionary events in this clade.

A shell can be thought of as a structure that is a tube that travels over time through‭ ‬360‭ ‬degrees of space.  These revolutions or turns of a coiled shell are called whorls,‭ ‬which are considered to spiral around an imaginary central axis.  This axis runs through the central column of the shell and is known as the columella. The speed at which the whorls enlarge can vary,‭ ‬and a continuous line separates each whorl and is referred to as a suture.  In most shells,‭ ‬the largest whorl of a shell is the last whorl‭ (‬body whorl‭)‬.  ‭ ‬The spire is considered to be all the whorls except the last. The apex is the tip of the spire and the opposite end is referred to as the base. The animal extends out of its shell through an opening called the aperture.

Shells can be viewed in apical,‭ ‬basal,‭ ‬apertural and abapertural views. ‭(‬The‭ "‬usual‭" ‬orientation of a shell is an apertural view,‭ ‬with the aperture toward the viewer and with the apex pointing up.‭)‬

A method for counting whorls is seen below.  First,‭ ‬the shell should be viewed from the apical view and then it should be determined where the first suture begins.  A line can be then drawn dividing the shell into two parts.  Whorls are counted from this line,‭ ‬and are estimated to a quarter of a whorl.

A shell can be viewed as a series of apertures that travel through time and space as the animal accretes‭ (‬i.e. builds‭) ‬its shell.  It is possible to trace the path of the aperture via coordinates of the center of each whorl’s aperture as well as the horizontal and vertical radius of the aperture.

This trajectory can be graphically and mathematically represented.  Once a mathematical formulation is made,‭ ‬it is then possible to vary parameters and modify the mollusk’s skeletogenesis.

The rate of neonatal and infant mortality in Indonesia remained rather static for the last ten years.  While the country is on track to meet many of the Millennium Development Goals, such as the water and sanitation targets, the rates of improvement for child and maternal health are woefully short of the improvements needed to meet their target goals by 2015.  The multiple reasons for these shortcomings will be discussed below, and point to a need to strengthen the health system rather than focus on programmatic interventions.
	Indonesia has made improvements in the number of births with a skilled health worker attending, with 72% of births now meeting this target.  That being said, this category still includes traditional workers, such as midwives, who cannot provide medical interventions should the pregnancy be complicated (hence the large percentage of maternal deaths caused by hemorrhage).  In other words,  the improvements made in this particular indicator are somewhat misleading and there is still much work to be done.  In addition, there has been a decline in the percentage of diarrheal cases in children under five years treated by a health professional.  While data on postnatal care is incomplete, it is clear that this area is also of concern, with low rates across the country.
	Cesarian-section rates are still lower than should be expected, around 4%.  The c-section rates additionally point to another concerning issue.  While the rate of c-section is 7% in urban settings, it is only 2% in rural.  This points to the problem of equity of coverage across the country.  Clearly access to healthcare services is focused around urban areas.  Another issue of access concerns vertical equity.  There is a 27% gap in service utilization between the poorest and richest quintiles.  Clearly the poor are finding it much more difficult to access healthcare services, likely due to out of pocket costs.
	In discussing next steps towards improving neonatal and maternal care indicators, the most basic question is how to most effectively address the lack of service.  Specifically, should Indonesia develop program-specific approaches or strengthen the overall health system without focusing on pre and post-pregnancy care for the mother and child.  There is no question that programmatic approaches to solve the problems outlined above are attractive.  Not only do “vertical approaches” that target one sector of improvements have much more targeted, manageable objectives, they also generally generate faster results.  There are some drawbacks to keep in mind, however.  One major drawback is that investing heavily in programming for one particular area of the health sector often means that funding for other areas suffers and human resources will flock towards working in that area that has more resources (the effect of international funding to HIV/AIDS and its effect on the family planning sector is one example).  In addition, running multiple parallel programs for one area results in duplication of services that are also uncoordinated between programs.  This leads to an increase in forms and paperwork for supplies and funding.

‎	‏The classification of Popular Music has grown over the past‭ ‬100‭ ‬years to include so many genres that it is difficult to definitively list them all. Complicating matters,‭ ‬most if not all genres—rap,‭ ‬rock,‭ ‬country,‭ ‬jazz,‭ ‬folk,‭ ‬just to name a few—have spawned multiple sub and sub-sub genres within their domain.  Arguably the sub-genre of Heavy Metal rock has become one of the most diverse and expressive genres of all popular music in the past‭ ‬40‭ ‬years. It is expressive because it displays a wide range of emotions,‭ ‬although they tend to lean toward the darker side of the spectrum. It is diverse in that quite soon after the beginnings of the genre,‭ ‬people started to realize that it had real flexibility and started to take advantage of it to create their own sub-genre,‭ ‬which then was followed by sub-sub-genres,‭ ‬and the chain continues until today. 

Today we have reached a point in the heavy metal movement where there are so many niches of groups that it is hard to determine what exactly heavy metal is. It has grown to incorporate so many themes from other genres,‭ ‬but like everything else,‭ ‬it spawned from somewhere. In order to properly understand the metal music that exists everywhere today,‭ ‬one must first understand what the metal movement is,‭ ‬and why it’s a movement rather than just a genre.

‎	‏Metal is,‭ ‬in many ways,‭ ‬a movement defined by darkness. Metal can be considered a‭ “‬music of more‭”—‬more bass,‭ ‬more volume,‭ ‬more violence,‭ ‬more theatricality. Less primitivism,‭ ‬more chops‭; ‬people in metal bands really know how to play their instrument,‭ ‬and it comes through in the music. Metal is also—although it may not come as a surprise—a movement that is heavily drug induced. There was a psychedelic drug boom in the mid-70‭’‬s that led to people getting crazier,‭ ‬leading to them to make crazy,‭ ‬other-worldly records,‭ ‬using the drugs as a scapegoat for their creation. It possesses many dark,‭ ‬visceral qualities,‭ ‬which was very new to the music scene because a large amount of popular music had qualities that weren’t true to the darker side of the emotional spectrum. Also,‭ ‬later generations of metal have taken some of their influence from the dark,‭ ‬visceral qualities that were so present in the Romantic Era. Lyrics such as the following express the darkness that is such a staple of the movement:‭ (‬Byrne‭)‬


	
These lyrics from Helter Skelter display the darker side of the Beatles. It exhibits an up and down,‭ ‬supposedly that of drugs. This song is considered by some to be one of the first Heavy Metal songs. It was a response to a Rolling Stones song that was also on the heavier,‭ ‬darker side. The Beatles wanted to prove that they could be just as heavy as the Stones,‭ ‬so they put that song on‭ ‬The White Album.

A few decades before the Surrealist artists began painting their dreamlike works, the artist Henri Rousseau was carefully crafting his own dreams, literally and figuratively. The Dream, a 1910 painting by the famous Post-Impressionist artist, represents not only a woman in awe at the wonders of the land she visits within a dream, but also Rousseau’s own personal dreams and goals as a painter. Since beginning his work, he dreamed of recognition, acceptance, and praise by other artists and art lovers, and found that he was faced with a difficult internal dilemma to achieve this aspiration. The Dream is Henri Rousseau’s work that best reflects his career-long internal struggle: to either conform to or mimic certain styles of painting in order to be accepted by the critical art world he so adored, or to allow himself to be creatively independent and unique, leaving his own path as he went.
Before one can analyze The Dream through this perspective, one must first be somewhat familiar with Rousseau’s biographical story. Henri Rousseau was born on May 21, 1844, in the town of Laval in northwest France. His father was a tinsmith and hardware dealer who “enjoyed bourgeois prosperity” (Shattuck 47). Growing up, he received no formal training in the arts; instead, he was employed until the age of forty working for France as a gabelou, or employee of the municipal toll service, although he received the misnomer sobriquet of douanier, a customs inspector (Shattuck 46). The death of his first wife, Clémence, which followed the deaths of eight infant children, left Rousseau with only one child, a daughter named Julia, and immense grief (Shattuck 49). He therefore hoped to take refuge in a new life and pursued painting to offer him comfort and fresh beginnings. Unlike contemporary colleagues of Rousseau who sentimentalize and romanticize the peasant in painting, he is essentially a folk painter and has the hopes and dreams of the average member of his class.
Rousseau’s obsession with being accepted by the art world is somewhat understandable when evaluated in context: as discussed, he was not only uneducated in the ways of formal painting and began his career at a much older age, but he was producing works at the same time as many other talented and better-known modern artists. Though working for many years already, Rousseau did not begin to receive proper recognition for his art until around the same time that Matisse had begun crafting a reputation as an artist. In the book Modern French Painters, author Jan Gordon asserts that the two, while technically competitors in the art arena, were different not only in style and subject matter but also their reasons for painting in the first place: “Matisse was a painter who conceived a terror of painting in a trite way, while Rousseau’s desire was to paint a picture so conventional that he would be admitted to the Artiste Français” (92).

Many a great thinker has postulated an intimate connection between ethics and aesthetics, between truth and beauty. I believe that at a fundamental level there is a reason for this. As John Keats says in “Ode on a Grecian Urn”, “Beauty is truth, truth beauty- That is all / Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know.” Much of what we know in life is learned via education or experience. However, we seem to appreciate ethics and aesthetics, as Keats implies, without being taught in these expected ways. Both ethics and aesthetics are an attempt to describe rather then prescribe. Our studies of morality and beauty are, for the most part, attempts to explain why a piece of art or literature is beautiful, or why an action is moral, rather than a set of rules for judging, or creating, good art or moral behavior. 
	More to the point, criticism of art or morals is never able to fully capture the essence of what is good or what is beautiful. A conversation about the worth of da Vinci's Mona Lisa, for example, may center around concepts like foreground, background, contrast, or cultural context, but in the end, these do not describe why it is good art. Rather, when one is asked about a favorite work of art or literature it is common to hear a phrase similar to, “There's just something about it” preceding a more complex or critical explanation. I believe that both art and morals can never be completely reduced to a description of their qualities. As Flannery O'Connor says, “A story is a way to say something that can't be said any other way . . . you tell a story because a statement would be inadequate.” No matter how completely we describe the properties of a work of literature, there is something transcendent which is still left. I believe that ethics has this same property. As Wittgenstein says, “It is clear that ethics cannot be expressed. / Ethics is transcendental. / . I suggest that it is this “something”, this je ne sais quoi, which is art and morality's most powerful attribute, and that this transcendental nature of both ethics and aesthetics provides a connection point between them.
	I believe that morality and art are so closely related because we experience both of them most powerfully at a noumenally, to use a Kantian term. They impact us at a level that can be experienced, but not fully explained. This link is even stronger when it comes to the art of literature. As McKean says, “What most distinguishes literature from the other arts, what is, in truth, unique about the art, is its moral quality. It may be that moral standards are inappropriate to other arts, music, for instance, but they seem to be as relevant to literature as they are to life itself. Living necessarily involves values. . . . Literature is important to us precisely because of the values we find there” .

The Germany of today is considered a strong force, a united country with its own blend of culture from within the shadows of the alps in München, all the way to Baltic sea city of Kiel.  The same culture can be felt from Köln on the river Rhine, through the centre of Germany to the Saxon city of Dresden located on the Elbe. With such a unique culture, it shouldn't be surprising that Germany as we now know it comes from several different sources, and tribes. 

Germania is the ancestral land of the Germans. The origins of the name are highly disputed among scholars and historians. Tacitus claimed that the name came from a Germanic Tribe known then as Tungrians, and that they had previously been known as Germans before they crossed the Rhine and battled the Gaulish forces (Tacitus, 98.) Julius Caesar first used the word “Germanus” in his commentary on the Gallic Wars where he put down the Gauls and battled with Germanic tribes which crossed the Rhine often under mischievous premisses. He took this word from The Gauls themselves, and used it to distinguish between those which he had conquered (The Gauls) and those which he had not. While the origin is uncertain, some believe it referred to a neighbor in the Gaulish language. In the first chapter, of his first book on these wars, Julius Caesar notes: “Germans, who dwell beyond the Rhine, with whom they (The Gauls) are continually waging war.....They contend with the Germans in almost daily battles.” (Julius Caesar, 50-40 BC) Others claim the meaning comes from the spear that they used in warfare, known as a ger (O.E.D, 2010), or perhaps from the Old Irish word garim meaning “to shout”, which indicated the Germans were loud, or noisy. (Names of Germany) 

 The early Roman historian Tacitus recorded in his AD 98 writing “De Origine et situ Germanorum”, which told of the origins of the Germans, that “I should regard (The Germans) as aboriginal, and not mixed at all with other races through immigration or intercourse. For, in former times it was not by land but on shipboard that those who sought to emigrate would arrive.......Who would leave Asia, or Africa, for Italy for Germany, with its wild country, its inclement skies, its sullen manners and aspect, unless indeed it were his home?(SIC)” (Tacitus, 98) 

And who would leave Rome for Germania? Certainly not the Romans, not yet at least. They would send out their conquests into the lands of Germania for goods, and lead the occasional land campaign but in the end they mostly returned back home to their sprawling empire. So as the Germanic tribes began appearing in the middle of the first century, they lived on the borders of the Roman Empire and traded their goods taken from the land, and their skills by serving within the ranks of the Roman army, (Ozment, 2005 pg. 17.)

The play Twelfth Night seems to say that although disguise is in fact useful in perpetrating long bouts of deception, in the end a person must reject that newly formed guise, or else risk losing themselves forever in the process. A big problem with ending a deception, however, is that one may find themselves alienated in the process. Therefore, in the end, one must decide between one’s own self preservation, or the preservation of relationships with those around them. For although some will respond neutrally to discovering that they’ve been tricked, still others will not take the deception so lightly, and will be likely be offended by the whole charade.
The topic of deception in gender role reversal is especially problematic, because it brings up many side issues, perhaps the most important one being, why? Why does the subject feel the need to shirk their own identity and take up a disguise in the form of the opposite gender? In Viola’s case, it is obviously a form of self protection.: “I’ll bring you to a captain in this town/ Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help/ I was preserved to serve this noble count…” (5.1.247-249)
Having newly arrived in a foreign land, Viola feels it necessary to pretend to be a man to protect herself from would be attackers. Viola’s plan works, but it also alienates her from the women around her, cutting her off from an important support system. To make matters worse, she is apparently so convincing at appearing to be a man that Olivia confuses her with Sebastian, and in effect falls in love with her. “Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay.” (5.1.138) On top of that, she also has to deal with suppressed romantic desires between her and Orsino: “Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times/ Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.” (5.1. 260-261)
Although this may be a somewhat progressive attitude, to the modern reader, Twelfth Night may be seen as an illustration of how deception may help facilitate the unveiling of suppressed emotions, especially in the cases of Olivia and Orsino. Certain passages seem to hint that the aforesaid characters may have unexpressed subconscious desires that the appearance of Viola/Cesario forces them to deal with. For instance, is Olivia attracted to Cesario because Cesario appears to be a man, or does Olivia really secretly harbor feelings for women? One would argue that this is probably not the case, because Shakespeare’s character Olivia seems more likely to be parodying those people of his time period who judge others only upon their looks. 
This is evidenced by the ease with which Olivia switches her romantic ardors from Cesario to Sebastian, and begins to regard Cesario/Viola as family rather than a love interest: “A sister, you are she.” (5.1.315)

German colonial rule has been noted by various observers for its brutality, notably with respect to the genocide of the Ovaherero and Nama in German South West Africa. Of course nothing so broad as an entire colonial empire can be accounted for by such a simple description. The German colonial empire was as varied in policies and ruling style as it was in geography. Educational provision across the colonies was similarly diverse. When the British took over German East Africa (Tanganyika) in 1919, they found a large population of educated and literate Africans. German educational efforts in Kamerun and other colonies were also praised by contemporary authors. 
The situation in South West Africa (present-day Namibia) presented a stark contrast.  Unlike in East Africa, where the government established state schools and played a prominent role in the education of the natives, in South West Africa the task of native education was left almost entirely to missionary societies that received limited government support. The government did however invest significant resources towards the education of Europeans in the colony, establishing s system of state schools as well as more heavily supporting and regulating missionary schools. These educational policies had longstanding effects on South West Africa, even after German rule. While other German colonies boasted significant numbers of literate and educated Africans, in South West Africa “the overwhelming majority of the population remained untouched, uneducated, and illiterate.” Various social, political, and economic factors led to the divergent experience of South West Africa. This paper seeks to expand the discussion by identifying these factors and paying particular attention to new research on the attitudes of settlers and colonial authorities to native Africans.
There is a wealth of literature dealing with education in the German colonial empire specifically. Most of these sources are in German and were written in the early twentieth century, during or shortly after the period of German colonial rule. The aim of early works was primarily to describe the features of educational systems in these colonies. Later writings in English expanded the discourse through comparative studies of education in the various German colonies and more detailed analyses of specific aspects of education. These studies illustrated significant differences in the educational systems of different colonies. The most prominent work to explicitly address the topic of this paper is Cohen’s study of education in South West Africa and East Africa. Cohen compares the educational systems of the two colonies and discusses the factors that account for the differences between them. According to Cohen, the large settler population of South West Africa explains many of the distinguishing aspects of the colony’s educational system.
Compared to Germany’s other colonial possessions, South West Africa had a moderately temperate climate, although much of the territory is covered by arid desert. The European population of South West Africa reflected the relatively hospitable conditions. By 1913 nearly 15,000 whites lived in South West Africa, while only 5,336 lived in the colony with the next largest settler population, East Africa.

The United States of America and Mexico are an example of two nations which at one time were beset by an enduring rivalry which spanned 57 years, from 1836 to 1893. (Diehl and Goerts 2000 p. 145).  The high-water mark of this rivalry was the Mexican-American War of 1846-1848, where the United States attacked and defeated Mexico and secured for itself Texas and the American Southwest as new territory.  Many other clashes happened between the two nations, finally abating just before the First World War.   The rivalry began as Americans and Mexicans clashed on key issues such as religion, culture and tradition and had a major clash of material interests (Schmitt 1974 p. 30-31).   
	This is not unlike many other nations who have an enduring rivalry with a neighbor.  Nations which share a border tend to have clashes of interests which lend to the creation of rival positions between the nations.  The United States and Mexico are not unlike many other enduring rivalries between nations which share a common border.  David M. Pletcher (1977) states that “Only in Mexico and Cuba can one find long-lasting overarching American diplomatic problems” (p. 41).  Indeed, both of these nations are geographically close to the United States and have been rivals to the United States, while other nations in Latin America enjoy and have enjoyed good relations with the United States.   
	Religious issues created a rift between the two nations, a problem which has beset many nations through history.  Sally Frahm (2001) states that ”if in the twentieth century Americans were opposed to fascism and communism, in the eighteenth and nineteenth they were opposed to Catholicism and monarchy”  (p.86).  Not unlike the Cold War’s rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union was part ideological struggle and part a competition over interests each nation deemed vital. In this case, however, the ideological struggles weren’t based on the political structure but on instead the religious preferences of the United States and Mexico.  This distrust grew from the distrust between the English and Spanish.  Inheriting these feelings of distrust from their former colonial rulers was a major obstacle in the establishment of amiable foreign relations between the United States and Mexico.
	Diehl and Goerts (2000) list 17 disputes between Mexico and the United States in the 57-year rivalry period.   The majority of disputes between the rivalry period described by Diehl and Goerts are territorial issues relating to border raids from Mexican territory into Mexico and other frontier problems.  Border raids by bandits and outlaws from on American border towns were a major problem which remained until both the United States and Mexico exerted military force on their borders (Schmitt 1974 p. 97).  
Schmitt (1974) explains the rivalry between the two nation began to abate as “Mexico became clearly dependent on the United States in a substantial way” (p. 109) and finally ended as American ambitions “changed from territorial expansion to economic intervention into Mexico” (p.110) in the later part of the 19th Century.

Fifteen‭ ‬years ago I became suddenly and unexpectedly disabled by an illness I never knew existed. 

 I was a nurse at the time. I had chosen my profession out of a deeply entrenched need for the safety and security I didn't have as a child. ‭"‬You'll always be able to find work‭; ‬people will always get sick.‭" ‬was the mantra I heard over and over as I reached adolescence and beyond. So--‭ ‬even though my dream was to be a scientist or a journalist-preferably a little of both,‭ ‬I chose nursing. 

Nevertheless,‭ ‬there I was:‭ ‬46‭ ‬years old and single,‭ ‬no money in the bank to speak of and unable to work. To this day I am disabled,‭ ‬and after‭ ‬15‭ ‬years of living on Social Security Disability,‭ ‬I have literally nothing left that I can call‭ "‬mine.‭" ‬I get by,‭ ‬but every day is a struggle and an assault on my security,‭ ‬safety and self-esteem. Nothing in my life is certain anymore,‭ ‬yet,‭ ‬there is one thing that I know to be true. I could not have gotten by for all these years were it not for the help of my family and a few good friends,‭ ‬no matter how strong I was. And believe me,‭ ‬when real disaster strikes,‭ ‬you do not feel very strong at all. 

My point is that there will always be emergencies in life-big and small.  There are no guarantees and no matter how well one prepares,‭ ‬some things are just too big to overcome on your own. 

I agree wholeheartedly that we in the U.S. need to stop putting all of our eggs in big government's‭ "‬basket‭"; ‬Lord knows it is moldy‭ ‬and falling apart,‭ ‬anyway. Yet I would much rather see Americans learning to trust one another again‭–‬learning to help each other and to ask for help,‭ ‬rather‭ ‬than have each of us individually clambering out to the backyard to build fallout shelters. 

The Conservatives in the US talk about the‭ "‬rugged individualism‭" ‬that built this country‭; ‬but in truth,‭ ‬what kept our forefathers going in hard times wasn't rugged individualism,‭ ‬it was compassion,‭ ‬mutual respect and the sharing of resources. The pioneers who crossed the Rockies in wagon trains didn't make it to the coast by going it alone. 


So,‭ ‬by all means,‭ ‬be prepared. I am. I have a disaster kit‭; ‬first‭ ‬aid supplies,‭ ‬water purifying tablets and plastic sheeting and duct tape for the windows in the event of a biological attack. I have several flashlights and all sorts of batteries,‭ ‬lots and lots of candles and waterproof matches and canned goods,‭ ‬too. If‭ ‬you have the land and the resources for a small farm and the ability to can or preserve your own food-do it. It's a great idea,‭ ‬as is a wood stove,‭ ‬as long as you do not live in an apartment. 

But while you are at it,‭ ‬get to know your neighbors.

Sometime in the fifth or sixth century BCE, a prince who would one day be called Buddha was born. Over the course of his life, he renounced the world and became enlightened, and his teachings led to the formation of Buddhism—the most orthodox sect of which is known as Theravada Buddhism. The religion is around twenty five hundred years old; it looks different today than it did when Buddha was alive. This can be seen all over, for instance in the Theravada nation of Sri Lanka, where the annual water-cutting ceremony is observed. Monks and laymen alike participate in this ceremony, and it holds some religious significance, despite Buddha never teaching about any festivity of the sort. These differences run all the way from the superficial traditions to the soteriological core of the religion. The Theravada Buddhist community, both from the monastic perspective and from the lay perspective, has had to change its doctrinal principles over time. This can be attributed to forces both external and internal, both hostile and benign.
	There are a number of qualifying terms this discussion will make frequent use of. There is the concept of internal versus external. Here, an internal force is defined as a force borne of members of the Buddhasasana, regardless of monastic status. An external force is any force from non-Buddhists. A hostile force is any force that damages or intends to damage the Buddhist community—a force borne of a negative perception of Buddhism. A benign force is a force that does not wish to harm or help the Buddhist community—though it may end up doing one or the other as a byproduct. These terms will come up repeatedly throughout this discussion.
	First, it is important to investigate the basics of the religion—the doctrines that lie at the core of Theravada Buddhism. Buddhists seek refuge in the triple gem of the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha. The Dhamma is essentially comprised of the Tripitaka—the three baskets—of Buddhist text. The Sutta Pitaka contains all the Suttas, the Vinaya Pitaka contains the disciplinary rules, and the Abhidhamma Pitaka contains the metaphysical components of Buddhism. The metaphysical notions consist of things like Anatta—no soul, Dukkha—inherent suffering in life, and Anicca—impermanence of everything. Only by recognizing these concepts can one end Sansara, the cycle of death and rebirth, which happens continuously. Along with Sansara will end lobha—desire, dosa—hatred, and moha—delusion, when one becomes enlightened. In the Vinaya Pitaka, rules for life are set forth. For laymen, there are five precepts (I shall not kill, I shall not lie, I shall not steal, I shall not misbehave sexually, and I shall not take intoxicating substances). For monks, there are many more disciplinary rules to be followed. The most fundamental doctrinal notion in Buddhism is the notion of the four noble truths. First, Dukkha; the truth that life is suffering. Second, that attachment causes suffering. Third, that suffering can be overcome.
transformed_texts:
Culture aint no simple thing to pin down. It moves like smoke through the fingers of them that try to grasp it, defying what it is and what it aint both. They was them that tried to say all peoples of one kind acted the same way but that was foolishness and pride talking. The Russians aint all cut from the same cloth no more than the Japanese is all bent to please. A man that sets down at the bargaining table better know more than just stories and rumors about the folk across from him.

When a man walks in foreign places he carries his own world with him like a shadow that wont leave. He sees through eyes raised in different dirt and the comparisons come whether he wants them or not. The history of a people runs deep as groundwater and their fears and hates deeper still. Aint no point in trying to change what time and blood have wrought. A smart man learns to work within the walls others have built, specially when he comes to their table cap in hand. And if youre standing on soil that aint your own you best mind their ways and their beliefs lest you find yourself talking to empty chairs.

The corporate world aint much different. Each company's got its own tribe marks, its own dances. Some demand their folk work till the night grows old while others let them come and go like cats. You can see it in how they dress and how they talk, whether they speak plain or dance around meaning like folks at a fire. Some let their people give money where they please while others keep tight reins on charity like a miser with his purse. Even in one company the ways change from city to field, from coast to coast, like watching the land change color as you cross it.

Values is the bones beneath the skin of culture. They tell you why a man wont shame his boss even if it costs him dear, or why another will fight for every penny like it was his last. A man that means to deal with folk from other places better know these things fore he sets down at their table. But knowing the lay of the land aint enough. You got to know the man across from you, see what fire or ice burns in his personal heart.

The fool speaks of godlessness and darkness spills from his mouth like black oil. These words echo through time from the ancient psalms and ring in the writings of Anselm, that old philosopher who sought to trap God in the cage of human reason. Aquinas too walked these paths, his footsteps falling in the same dust. They were both hunters of the divine, tracking the same prey through different territories of thought.

We cannot speak of some shapeless deity here, some formless spirit that drifts through the minds of men like smoke. No. The God they sought was the God of scripture, terrible and merciful, who hung the stars like lanterns in the void. But neither man, for all their wisdom, could capture the whole of Him in their nets of logic.

Anselm believed the proof lay in the skull itself, in the dark chambers where thought dwells. He said that God existed in understanding and therefore must exist in fact, like a shadow that proves the existence of the thing that casts it. He wrote his arguments in circles, endless spirals that led inward to the same truth: that the mind itself contained the proof, that no external evidence was needed. Faith was the key that opened these doors.

But Aquinas walked a different road. He sought God in the physical world, in the turning of seasons and the falling of rain. He built five ladders of reason to climb toward heaven: change, cause, necessity, perfection, and order. Each rung was forged from cold logic, from the observable facts of existence. Like a man who finds a footprint in the sand and knows that something passed this way, Aquinas believed the world itself testified to its maker.

He thought faith unnecessary, that pure reason could lead men to God like a rope thrown down from heaven. As if the divine could be caught in a net of syllogisms, as if the infinite could be measured with finite tools. Both men searched for truth but found only pieces of it, like broken shards of a mirror reflecting different parts of the same sky.

The writers of old knew the ways of it. How to bend the mind of a reader toward some truth or feeling that lay dormant in the dark chambers of thought. Some ways worked better than others and Fitzgerald knew them all. In The Great Gatsby he wielded these tools like a craftsman at his forge, hammering out strange pairings of words that had no business being together yet somehow sang true in their wrongness. But it was in his use of color that the real alchemy took place. Gold and green and white and gray and the bloodied hues of red and pink all carried their own terrible weight.

The white and gray spoke of sameness and the crushing weight of conformity. White for the moneyed folk who thought themselves better, gray for what time had worn down to dust. They was everywhere in them early pages. Daisy and Jordan floating like pale ghosts in their white dresses, and Nick in his white flannels at that garish party, and Tom in his white shirt meeting his woman in secret. Even Catherine wore white like death itself, powdered pale as bone. Only at Gatsby's revelries did the white give way, them halls bleeding primary colors like some wounded thing.

The whiteness and grayness marked everything common and dead. The canyons of New York stood white and terrible, and the names of party guests faded to gray specters in Nick's memory. Apartment buildings lined up like slices of some endless white cake that would feed no hunger. The sameness stretched out across it all. Jordan and Daisy's white childhood, pristine and empty as fresh fallen snow. And in the valley of ashes everything turned gray - the cars, the land, even the people. Some Italian child gray as stone, and the old man selling dogs gray as time itself.

Then Fitzgerald turned these colors like weapons. When Daisy appeared again in her white dress and white car she wasn't no person no more but just another pale thing Gatsby wanted to possess, uniform as all the rest. The gray of her fur collar and the white of her dress before that final confrontation marked her as something faded and common, despite all Gatsby's dreams of her being otherwise.

They called it blessed land, this stretch of San Diego County where the sun hung like a copper coin and the earth gave forth its bounty without complaint. Tomatoes and citrus. Greens that grew wild and defiant. Squash and broccoli and herbs that had no names in the old tongue. The trees bore peaches and lemons and the bees made their honey in wooden boxes like small coffins stacked in rows. People would wait months, years even, to claim their share of this organic bounty, their names writ on lists that grew longer with each passing season.

The land remembered what came before. It remembered the poison and the chemicals that had seeped into its bones like original sin. But now it was clean. Pure. The birds returned and the soil grew rich with life that had been forgotten. You could walk these acres now, watching the hawks wheel overhead while children learned the ways of seeds and earth. The government men came with their papers and promises, speaking of programs and benefits, but the land cared nothing for such things.

They'd chosen a parcel near Potrero, a town that wasn't really a town at all. One hundred and sixty acres pressed against the Cleveland National Forest like a wound that wouldn't heal. Chaparral and grassland that had come across the ocean in some ship's hold, and oak trees that had stood witness to a thousand years of blood and dust. The bureaucrats had their plans and their lists of dying things - the kangaroo rat and the yellow-legged frog and butterflies with names like epitaphs. The owls that burrowed in the earth were vanishing too, as if they knew something about the future that men did not.

The Indians had lived here first, their fires marking the nights for centuries until the ranchers came with their cattle and their axes. Someone had claimed this land with a piece of paper, had cut the trees and grazed the grass until the earth forgot what it had been. Now it waited, patient as stone, while new farmers tried to make peace with its ghosts.

Blood ties run deeper than bone. Two brothers bound by flesh and fate and the terrible weight of their shared blood. In their eyes dance love and pride and jealousy and cruelty like ancient spirits that have no name. Brothers know each other in ways that God himself cannot fathom, each seeing in the other a mirror of his own soul. When darkness comes it comes like a thief and strips bare the truth of their bond whether that truth be blessed or damned. And there is always a price to be paid.

They walked through the swamp country, these two brothers, one whole and one broken, through tangles of vine and cypress knee where the mud sucked at their boots and the air hung thick as molasses. The older brother carried his pride like a weapon. He had wanted someone to race with through the pinewoods, to swim in the black waters of Horsehead Landing, to climb the great trees that stood like sentinels in the gathering dusk. Instead God had given him Doodle.

Doodle who was born wrong. Born with a heart that fluttered in his chest like a crushed bird. The doctors had shaken their heads and spoken in whispers but still he lived. The older brother remembered standing over the infant's cradle in the dark, thinking murderous thoughts, the pillow heavy in his hands. But then Doodle had smiled and something in that smile reached down into the darker places of the brother's heart and found there a terrible love that would not die.

Pride is a poison that works slow but sure. The brother could not accept what God had given him and so he set about to remake his brother in his own image. Through the swamps they went, through rain and sun, the lessons grinding on like the wheels of some infernal machine. Until that final day when the storm came and pride extracted its terrible price in blood.

The mind of man is a dark and tangled thing. A labyrinth of flesh and thought that has no beginning and no end. In the old days they said it was like marks pressed into wax or the dried ink upon papyrus leaves or the bound pages of books but now they speak of circuits and silicon and cold machine logic. All these are lies we tell ourselves to make sense of what cannot be understood.

The world comes at us raw and bleeding. Light and sound and heat pierce the fortress of skull and flesh and become something else entirely. Something electric. Something alive. The mind takes these wounds and transforms them again and again, like a blacksmith hammering crude ore into steel. When your eyes fall upon the black square set against white it is both bottom and top, like some inverse tower of babel reaching up and down at once. The bottom builds the thing from darkness and edges and borders while the top names it and knows it and calls it box.

There is a sentinel in the mind that stands watch over what passes through. It decides what matters and what don't, like some border guard at the gates of consciousness. The grass beneath your feet might as well be invisible but your name spoken across a crowded room rings like a church bell in your ears.

The mind must store what it knows in different vessels. Some hold for mere seconds like water in cupped hands while others last unto death. The way things are remembered aint simple. A word can be remembered for its shape or its sound or its meaning, like how a man might know a rattler by its pattern or its buzz or the poison in its fangs. Some say the short memories are like electricity running circles through the brain while the long ones are built into the very stuff we're made of.

They got maps for how all this knowledge fits together. Scientists and philosophers arguing over their models like prophets with their sacred texts. One says everything we know is tied together in a web of meaning, each thought connected to the next like beads on a string. Chair connects to table connects to wood and on and on into the darkness of the mind. But these are just more stories we tell ourselves in the night.

They called it a crisis but that word dont carry the weight of what came. Like some biblical plague it swept across the land in 2007, a darkness that consumed all before it. Men who'd built empires of paper and promises watched them crumble like ancient ruins. The unemployed walked the streets like ghosts. Houses stood empty, their windows dark eyes staring at nothing.

It started in the time of Clinton, back in 99 when the world was drunk on its own possibility. The government men came with their papers and their promises, telling the banks to give money to them that had none. Give it freely, they said, like it was water from a bottomless well. A man named Holmes wrote about it in the Times, seeing the shape of what was coming like a prophet in the desert. He spoke of Fannie Mae bending to the will of politicians, of storms gathering on the horizon, but none would listen.

They made new kinds of money magic then. Mortgages that shifted like desert mirages, securities backed by dreams, obligations built on debt stacked on debt like some mad child's tower of blocks. The whole country was betting on houses, leveraged to the teeth, tied together with strings of numbers and contracts that no man fully understood.

When it fell it fell hard. The great houses of money, five of them standing like pillars holding up the sky, found themselves holding four trillion in worthless paper. Bear Stearns and Merrill Lynch sold themselves for pennies like whores in a dying town. Lehman Brothers vanished like smoke. Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley crawled to the government begging for mercy and new chains to wear. Fannie and Freddie, them that started it all, fell into the government's hands like sick children, carrying five trillion in debt like original sin.

The world aint been the same since. Maybe it never will be. Some say we learned from it but men's memories are short and greed is a beast that never sleeps long.

The words lay there like dead things. Stories told and retold until they were nothing but bones picked clean by carrion birds. He knew exposition for what it was. A devil that whispered sweet promises of easy paths through the thorny wastes of narrative. Show dont tell they'd say but the devil cared nothing for such commandments.

He'd seen writers fall to it. Good ones too. Their words stretching out across endless pages like desert highways leading nowhere, telling everything and showing nothing. Characters born fully formed from their minds like clay golems, their histories laid bare in cold mechanical recitation. No blood. No breath. Just facts piled on facts until the weight of them crushed whatever life might have stirred beneath.

There was a woman once. The story told how she met a man and loved him and watched him die. Two pages of words that meant nothing. No pulse in them. No heat. The man never lived so he could not truly die. His voice never carried across the page, his hands never touched anything real. The woman's grief was just more words. Empty. Hollow. Like wind through dead trees.

The devil sits and whispers still. Tells you to pour out every detail, every fragment of history, every breakfast eaten and dream dreamed. A man was Air Force once, it says, runs a gas station now. Divorced twice. Fishes. Wants things he cant have. Ate eggs this morning in some diner somewhere. But the devil doesn't know that facts aint truth, that history aint story. The truth is in the spaces between facts, in the blood and bone and breath of things. In the showing of them.

The morning came cold and gray and the television flickered blue against the wall. Two broadcasts from Columbus, both bearing witness to the violence that men do.

First came word of Ashley where a man named Hostettler had put knife to wife. His face on the screen was darkness itself, eyes vacant like windows in abandoned houses. They gave it two minutes. No more was needed. The wife had no name, just the wounds counting her story.

Then there was the boy Buyers, eighteen summers old, shot down in Sharon Woods. No killer found, just SWAT men moving through morning shadows. They passed quick over this tale, like wind over dead grass, the way they always do when dark skin wears the victim's mask. White flesh gets the cameras rolling, gets the helicopters up, gets the mothers crying on screen. But brown and black flesh just bleeds quiet into yesterday's news.

A bullet had found the Med-Flight bird, .22 caliber singing through metal skin. Five thousand dollars to name the shooter. The money hung in the air like smoke.

Weather came next. Rain coming, they said. Thunder too. Numbers that meant nothing to the sky.

Then the UDF store on Clime Road. Another robbery. They spoke of the thief's darkness like it was all that mattered. Six foot tall. One fifty. Wearing cotton black as night. They lingered on his color like old men chewing tobacco.

Last was Rodriguez, the Texas man who'd moved green plants north for profit. Three hundred months they gave him. Not twenty-five years, like normal folk might say. Three hundred months. As if counting each one made the time more heavy. They named him Hispanic, though that truth changed nothing about his crime or his time.

The news ended. The screen went dark. Somewhere in the distance, thunder rolled.

They called them ETFs and they moved like wraiths through the digital ether of the exchanges, tracking indices and commodities and baskets of assets with a cold precision that mutual funds could never match. They were more fluid than their ancestors, trading like common stock on the exchange floor where men in dark suits watched numbers flash red and green on endless screens.

The benefits lay before them like bones in the desert. Diversification. The ability to sell short. Margin buying. Even a lone share could be had for the asking. And the cost, the expense ratios they called them, sat lower than any mutual fund that ever drew breath in the financial world. But there were darker things too. Commissions that had to be paid, like blood tribute to ancient gods, every time a trade crossed the wire.

The particular beast they called IHF roamed these electronic plains, and within its belly dwelt ten primary holdings that made up near sixty-four percent of its being. These holdings moved in concert like a pack of wolves, each one carrying its own weight in the greater whole. Some men said you could break them apart, reconstruct them in new ways that might yield better returns, better ratios. But such things were never certain in this wilderness of numbers.

They took to calculating the returns, working the numbers like ancient shamans reading entrails. The portfolio of ten showed returns six point eleven percent higher than the ETF itself, with a beta that ran point twelve lower. But numbers could lie, or tell half-truths, and so they sought statistical significance like prospectors panning for gold in muddy waters.

The standard deviations came next, normalized to one hundred percent, a mathematical ritual performed to divine whether these two portfolios truly walked different paths or merely appeared to do so in the shifting light of market days.

The numbers told a truth we didnt want to see. They fell like dead leaves in that third month, scattered and blown away by winds we could not control. Winter had come to New England as it always does, merciless and cold, and the bicycles stood abandoned like metal skeletons against the walls. The walkers too had vanished from the paths that crossed the campus grounds.

December brings its own kind of darkness. Not just in the sky but in the souls of those who dwell in these academic towers. They scurry between buildings bearing their burdens of papers and grades like penitents before some vengeful god. The logging of their journeys became a forgotten ritual, lost among the countless others that fill these days.

Then the holidays came and went like specters, taking with them the people who gave this place its pulse. January crawled back slow and cold as a wounded animal. February brought no salvation, no explanation for why the numbers stayed low like track marks in dirty snow.

Perhaps it was the nature of all such endeavors to burn bright at first then fade like embers in an untended fire. We tried to rekindle it with what we called the Carpool Challenge Week in March. A desperate measure maybe but it brought some life back to the dying flame.

The truth that gnawed at us was deeper though. These people, they loved their machines. The car was freedom itself, written into their blood like some ancient covenant passed down through generations. We tried to tempt them away with small offerings - paper promises to coffee shops and bookstores, local eateries and massages. But perhaps we should have dreamed bigger. A bicycle gleaming new under fluorescent lights. A hybrid car humming with promise. An electric vehicle silent as death itself.

The gifts we gave stayed the same while interest waned like daylight in December. If we had built up to something greater, something that spoke to that American hunger for the grand gesture, maybe we could have kept them. Maybe they would have stayed true to what we were trying to build. But we'll never know now. The numbers tell their own story and we can only read what's there, stark as bones in the desert.

I sat there in the dim light watching them old Edison reels spin, fifteen of them from the years 1895 to 1901, all of them trick films they called them. Strange illusions wrought from celluloid and light, crafted by men who knew the devil's arithmetic of splicing and cutting. Most of these phantasms followed the old ways, bound to their stages like prisoners to stakes, the camera fixed and unmoving as death itself, showing only what the eye could see from far off or middling distance, each film a singular vision like a dream that wont repeat.

The pictures showed themselves like theatrical spectres trapped in a box, all viewed straight on like you was sitting in them velvet seats watching vaudeville. The camera stood witness, unmoved and unmoving, while the players danced their sideways dance across the frame like marionettes on invisible strings. In one such film called Uncle Josh in a Spooky Hotel, made in the year 1900, the actors moved like specters from right to left, back and forth in their prescribed geometry, never daring to approach the glass eye that watched them.

They kept their distance too, these ghostly players. No close viewing of their faces was permitted, as if some unwritten law forbade it. Like watching a stage play from the cheap seats, you saw them whole or half-whole but never closer, keeping to the traditions of them theatrical shows where distance was a kind of proper modesty between performer and watcher.

Most curious was how these films held to the notion that one film meant one shot, though that wasnt the truth of it. They'd run a minute or less, depending on how fast the machine turned, telling their brief tales of vanishing acts and conjurer's tricks with barely a whisper of story to them. But there was deception even in this simplicity. Take that film about Mary Queen of Scots and her execution, made in 1895. Look close enough and you can see where they stitched together the moment when her head parts ways with her shoulders, though they meant for you to see it whole and seamless, like death itself.

The Gothic Novel stands as both ancient and new, a thing birthed from darkness and carried forth into light, like some terrible child of time itself. Watt called it what it was: old-new, though such words fail to capture the blood and bone of it. They spoke of it in whispers, some cursing its shallow heart while others praised what Burke named the terrible sublime, as if such words could contain the thing itself. 

Walpole's Castle stood first among them all, a dark sentinel rising from the marriage of ancient romance and modern telling. He took what was old - them theatrical pieces that spoke of death and gods and fate - and bound them to the new way of showing man's nature true upon the page. Gothic it was, gothic it remained, though that word had walked many paths before, marking peoples and times and ways of building that stood against the sky like accusations. The modern world saw it as something crude, primitive, yet it endured. The marriage of theatrical gothic with this new thing called novel gave it legs to walk through time, making it both dead and newborn with each reading.

The old ways of chivalry run through it like veins of ore through stone. That medieval learning, the making of knights, survived in Walpole's Castle though changed as all things must change. These writers, Walpole chief among them, saw in chivalry something lost to their time - honor and bravery and competence gone to dust in the modern world. They reached back through years dark as pitch to grasp at something they thought pure, something they could hold up against their failing present like a torch against the night. 

Walpole wrote in troubled times, when politics ran like poison through the veins of power and men spoke lies as easy as breathing. Maybe he saw in them old gothic times something better, something true that had died in the hearts of men who walked his streets and sat in his parliament. You can see it in his Frederic, that character drawn in lines of knightly virtue, a prince who knew suffering and carried it like a crown, thought dead at the hands of infidels. But even here the gothic shows its teeth, for Frederic stands too perfect, too pure, excess piled upon excess until the thing threatens to topple under its own weight.

The chain moves like a great serpent through the land, from raw earth to finished good, from order to delivery, all of it bound by invisible threads of commerce and need. Oliver who was a consultant had named it thus in 1982 though the thing itself was ancient as trade itself. Six parts it had, like chambers in some mechanical heart: production and supply and inventory and location and transport and last the knowing of things, information dark and precious as oil.

The first of these was production and it was the foundation on which all else stood or fell. Men in offices would study the markets like augurs reading entrails, trying to divine what the people wanted and how much of it they'd pay for. They'd send their findings down through the chain of command like prophets of old til the decision was made: what would be built and where and how many. The wrong choice here would echo through time like a gunshot in an empty church, costly in both coin and hours.

He remembered the great retailers where he'd worked in younger days. Walmart. Target. Each with their own scripture of process, their own gospel of method. Every worker wore the prescribed vestments, every truck unloaded according to ancient rite. The smallest deviation could send ripples through the whole operation like a stone dropped in still water.

The second link was supply, a thing of strategy and partnership. Managers would sit in their towers and determine what each facility could do best, like generals plotting campaigns. Sometimes they'd reach out to other companies, forging alliances in pursuit of what they called velocity - that holy grail of quality and flexibility wedded to the twin gods of cost and efficiency. The divisions were many, each with its own machines and men, its own specialties honed sharp as knives. These decisions too could make or break a company, send it soaring or drag it down into the dust of bankruptcy.

They came in those times the great tomes bound in leather and gilt, stories of drawing rooms and high society folk wrought with detail and ceremony like some terrible pageant. Yet there were others. Dark tales. Tales of foundlings and orphans and the mad people on the moors. Oliver Twist and Wuthering Heights stood apart from the rest, carried within them something older and more terrible. Something that gave power to their people on the page, showed what drove them and what ate at their souls like carrion birds.

He walked between Sikes and Crackit and they argued, their voices like wind through dead leaves, and he knew he spoke to them though he could not hear his own voice. Then came the gunshot. A sound like God's own thunder. Shouts rose up and lights bloomed in the darkness and something unseen took him away through the chaos and the night. Through it all pain walked with him like some dark companion, never leaving, never sleeping.

The books showed these fever dreams, these visions that came like prophets in the night. In Oliver Twist they revealed the boy's heart, showed what pained him and what truths he knew about the world of thieves and murderers around him. When the shooting came again in the twenty-eighth chapter Oliver lived it anew, dreamlike, while he sought help that might not come. The passage told of his powerlessness, how the events moved through him like a river through a canyon, unstoppable. His mind fractured and he saw Sikes and Crackit again, fever-wrought apparitions in the dark. The shot came again but this time the pain was already there, dwelling in his flesh like some unwanted tenant. He was carried away by hands he could not see and did not fight against. The question hung in the air like smoke - whose will had brought this about? Not Oliver's. Never Oliver's. He had become something acted upon, not an actor. Fagin's influence had worked its way into him like poison, teaching him defeat, teaching him despair.

The day went and the darkness came. No day at all really. Just a brief lightning flash of light between seas of darkness. Night came on again vast and terrible in its silence yet brief in its hours.

I reckon it was two years past when I worked with them children after their schoolin was done for the day. Them that needed help with their studies. English and readin was what I knew best and one day this instructor come to me about a boy. Adrian was his name. Third or fourth grade, I dont recall which. The boy had trouble with his letters and I watched him struggle with the shapes on the page like they was some ancient text carved in stone by forgotten peoples. Some letters he knew true as sunrise but others might as well been hieroglyphs cut deep in obsidian. He spoke English pure as any native son but his blood was Latino, that much was certain.

We worked at it day after day until his mother come in one afternoon while the others was gone on some excursion. She stood there in the doorway like a dark bird, not a word of English in her. Just Spanish flowing like water from a deep well. My own Spanish was poor but we managed somehow and thats when it hit me like God's own thunder - the boy could read fine enough but the English alphabet was foreign country to him. Whether this knowledge ever served him I cant say.

This here story speaks to something deeper in these borderlands, specially in California where the tongue of one land bleeds into another. Sometimes the wall between languages aint as clear as we might think. Even them children who speak English like they was born to it sometimes cant read the words proper. We all know this truth but what's to be done? For Adrian it was simple enough - teach him his letters and sounds in English. But for them that barely speak the language its like trying to build a house in quicksand. Aint no single answer neither. Dual language learning, throwing em in with English speakers, private teaching, special classes - none of these alone is gonna fix what's broke. The answer lies in weaving them all together like strands in a rope.

The dual language way of teaching, that's something worth considering. Not just for them Spanish speakers but for all of em. Studies show these children do better than their peers though some folk fear it like they fear what they dont understand. They say its wasteful but they're wrong as wrong can be. If we was to make this the way of things instead of just sometimes, every child would grow stronger for it. But how to do such a thing? We cant expect every teacher to speak both tongues - that aint realistic. But there aint no reason we cant have helpers who do.

From youth we are told of something greater than ourselves. Something vast and unknowable that stretches beyond the boundaries of mind and reason. They shepherd the young ones to wooden buildings with crosses hung like dead things on the walls or to temples where old men murmur ancient words in tongues long forgotten. Some take what their fathers gave them and hold it close like a talisman against the dark while others cast it away declaring themselves alone in the void. All of them searching. All of them lost.

The old man said cardinal and the word hung there in the wet air between us. We sat watching the rain beat against the tin roof like tiny fists demanding entry, the water coursing through the gutters and drowning the flowers that mother had planted years ago before she too was gone. His eyes fixed on some distant point where memory and rain became one thing. The clothes that once fit him proper now hung loose on bones that seemed too sharp beneath his skin. The hair thin and grey where once it had been thick and black. Neither of us spoke of what was coming. Neither of us could bear to make it real with words. I moved my chair closer to his and together we watched the rain fall through the June darkness like tears from an indifferent god.

He died in December. Five days after I turned twenty-two years old. The doctors with their medicines and machines had kept him breathing past their own predictions but what good was breath without peace. What kind of god would craft such torment. In the darkness I spoke no prayers for I knew if there was a god he had turned from us long ago like a father abandoning his children to wolves.

I did not watch him die. Could not watch the body that had made me turn cold and still. Memory is a cruel thing that shows us what we most wish to forget and I wanted only to remember him alive. He would not have wanted me there anyway. His only child watching the light go out of him. I lay in my bed for three days waiting for word.

No word came.

The man Taylor of Caroline walked in the early light of the Republic like a pilgrim seeking truth in barren fields. He was a tiller of soil first and always but the earth and brief congress with matters of state had forged in him something hard and crystalline and pure. His voice rang clear against the gathering dark of federal power and rang clear for the freedom of men to work their own destiny. The soil was his scripture and from it he drew all manner of revelation about how men ought govern themselves.

He saw in this new land a terrible possibility. Here there were no ancient ghosts to bind the minds of men, no rotting institutions to poison the well of self-governance. He held that men were born with certain rights sacred and inviolable and these rights moved together like a school of fish, each one depending on the others, and should one be taken the rest would surely follow leaving naught but empty water behind. These freedoms, he declared, must remain forever beyond the reach of any government fashioned by human hands.

Taylor knew the duality that lived in the hearts of men. Good and evil dwelled there like conjoined twins sharing one heart, and any government worth its salt must account for both. He wrote that government being the work of men must carry in it all the virtue and vice that men possess. The principles he called good were those that protected what a man owned and worked for, that made the earth yield its bounty, that kept the moneylenders from the temple. He believed even corrupt men serving in a righteous system would be bound to do right, though their hearts might burn with greed.

Like a prophet in the wilderness he called for the Constitution to be read pure and clean, stripped of all ornament and interpretation. The federal beast must be kept small and lean lest it grow fat on the wealth of the people and turn tyrannical. But he warned against reading the words too simply, for without understanding the minds of those who wrote them, even holy words could be twisted to serve unholy ends. And above all other documents he held high the Declaration, for in it he saw written clear as morning light the truth that these states were sovereign and separate, not one nation but many joined in common cause.

He stood and looked down and the looking was a thing without emotion or connection to the world of men. His mind moved like water over stones, touching but never holding, seeing but never knowing. Thoughts came and went like wind through dead grass.

Once there had been a book. Some artist had given it to him. Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain it was called and in it were the secrets of how men make pictures from the world. How they take the chaos of creation and put it in a box. How they frame God's work in squares of their own making. Take a kitchen with its bowl of fruit and make it something else. Something smaller. Something a man could understand.

But there wasnt no frame for what he saw now. No box to put it in. No way to make it smaller or more manageable. It just was what it was and he stood before it like a pilgrim at a shrine he never wanted to find. Picasso had his blues and Monet his greens but what lay before him now was brown. Brown like the earth. Brown like death.

His fingers found the handle. Touched it like a gunslinger touching steel. The water moved in its porcelain bowl like some imprisoned sea. Matter broke away and scattered and was gone. He flushed again. The brown thing stayed. Stuck there like original sin. Like something that had always been there and always would be.

He stood in his green tie that choked at his throat like a hangman's rope. Stood and looked at what some nameless pilgrim had left behind in this Rite Aid temple. The toilet paper came off the roll like bandages for the dead. He wrapped his hand until it was white as bone. Bent like a man in prayer. Reached into that water like reaching into hell itself...

They die on the roads. Young ones. Their blood dark and pooling on asphalt while chrome glints in the dying light. The men in white coats and their papers speak of minds not yet formed, of brains still raw and reaching. Inexperience sits like a demon in the passenger seat. The vehicle rolls. It speeds. It leaves the known path for darker territories.

They travel in packs, these young ones. Like wolves but without the wisdom. Numbers from men who study such things in California tell a truth that any fool could see - that death rides closer when youth congregates behind glass and steel.

The state men tried to fix it with paper laws. No driving in darkness. No carrying others who share their tender age. But these are just words on paper, thin as ash and just as lasting.

The truth sits harder. These children, these drivers barely weaned from their mothers' breast, cannot bear the weight of steel and speed and responsibility. Even at eighteen, says the doctor man Zuckerman, the blood runs too hot. The need for danger pulses like a second heart. Wait, he says. Wait until the fire cools.

If we dont wait, if we keep putting keys in hands still soft with youth, the roads will drink more blood. The children of the boom times are coming, millions strong, ready to take their turn at the wheel of death.

The fix is simple but hard like all true things. Keep them from the wheel until eighteen summers have passed. Let them learn in classrooms and watched spaces. Make them prove their worth with hours behind the wheel under watchful eyes. California demands its pound of flesh - six hours watched and fifty more with elders present. Let it be so everywhere, from sea to burning sea.

This aint new thinking. But truth rarely is.

They called it CAPD and it was a thing that lived in the brain and made the world sound wrong. Not wrong like deafness or the absence of sound but wrong in the way that the mind takes what it hears and makes sense of it. Like a broken translator working between the ear and the understanding.

The disorder stood three-legged. First was what it was. Then how they found it. Last was what teachers could do when they found such a child in their rooms, lost in the sound.

It began in the fifties when they didnt know what to call it. Italian doctors with names like prayers - Bocca, Calearo, Cassinari - they started testing children who could hear but couldnt understand what they heard. Then Kimura came with his tests of competing sounds in different ears like some kind of auditory inquisition.

The way it showed itself was manifold and terrible. Sometimes the afflicted couldnt tell where sounds came from in the world, like they lived in a universe without direction. Sometimes they couldnt tell one sound from another or recognize patterns that should have been clear as desert stars. They might miss the way a voice changes when it means something different than what the words say. Sound eating sound. Everything heard but nothing understood.

To find it they had to watch and test and measure. Audiologists and speech people and doctors all with their different tools like mechanics trying to diagnose an engine they couldnt see. They had questionnaires and tests but none of them perfect. None of them sure. They would put sounds in both ears at once and ask what was heard, like trying to catch two rabbits running in opposite directions. Sometimes they would measure the very electricity of hearing itself, tiny signals in the ear like distant lightning.

The children come to us broken and we aim to mend them though we know not how. They come with their eyes vacant and their spirits crushed by those who should have nurtured them. I seen it in my wanderings through the halls of human misery. The calling came to me as it comes to all who walk these paths. Service. Respect. A moral compass pointing true north in a world gone mad.

I walked among the lost souls in school halls watching them medicate their pain with whatever poison they could find. The darkness in their eyes spoke volumes no book could hold. After my schooling at Piedmont I drifted like a leaf on water until fate brought me to that house where the boy sat. Sixteen years old. Terror written across his face plain as scripture. His parents had done things. Things that leave marks deeper than flesh.

The law stood impotent. The badges gleaming dully in the afternoon sun as I spoke to them of psychology degrees and human suffering. They sent me in to speak with the parents who sat like guilty thieves in their own home spinning tales of manipulation and simple disputes that weren't simple at all. Their words hung in the air like smoke from a fire that had consumed something precious.

Justice is a word we use like a talisman against the darkness but the darkness comes anyway. Society preaches individuality while demanding conformity like some mad priest speaking in tongues. I fought back in my own way. Hair the color of nuclear sunsets. Steel through flesh marking rebellion. Standing with the outcasts and the different because different is what we all are under our masks of sameness. The world tells us to be alike but the soul screams for freedom. I heard that scream and answered it. Still do. Always will.
