They would make their clumsy advances like wandering pilgrims seeking salvation but finding only empty churches. She pondered this peculiarity deep into the night hours, searching for some truth in the darkness of her own mind but finding no answers that satisfied.

The house she dwelt in was mostly peaceful. Her folks carried a quietness about them like old leather worn smooth, never raising voices against one another and seldom against their daughter save for when she tested the bounds of her freedom. She was wild energy contained in young flesh, carrying herself with a brightness that drew others to her like moths to flame yet harboring kindness beneath it all.

But peace aint a permanent state in this world. She was walking the rooms seeking something she couldn't name when her mothers scream tore through the quiet like a knife. It was a sound that carried pain and fear wrapped together in one terrible note. She found her mother splayed on the kitchen floor, each breath carrying small sounds of agony like wind through dying leaves. Hospital, the mother managed through gritted teeth. The girl gathered her up like something precious and broken, thankful for the strength in her arms that the iron had given her. She laid her mother across the backseat of the car like a funeral offering and drove.

The hospital carried its own particular perfume of death and cleanliness but she noticed none of it, her mind fixed only on the woman who bore her. She carried her burden through those sterile halls calling out like some ancient herald announcing tragedy. White-coated figures materialized from the fluorescent gloom, whisking her mother away on wheels while she stood abandoned to worry and wait.

All this because of a vase perched too high and a stepstool that proved treacherous.

They sought truth in numbers and blood. The Mediterranean way of eating, ancient as the stones themselves, whispered promises of longer life through the statistics. Not some simple thing but a dance of olive oil and fish, of grain and fruit born from sun-scorched earth. No potatoes. The flesh of beasts used sparingly. Wine in moderation, like the old ones knew.

Before them others had walked this path. Studies spoke of hearts beating longer, of death's shadow falling later for those who followed the old ways. The fat-fearing prophets had been wrong. Their low-fat gospel crumbled like dust while the Mediterranean truth endured, especially among the heavy of flesh.

They watched the nurses. Seventy-four thousand eight hundred and eighty-six women, each carrying her own history of health and hurt, none touched yet by the sugar sickness or the heart's betrayal. From eleven states they came, marking their food on papers six times across twenty years, faithful as pilgrims. Most stayed true to the end.

The counters of numbers verified everything. When death came they checked the records, the certificates, the cold facts of autopsy. Some deaths they called probable when papers failed them, ghostly statistics haunting the margins of truth. They measured the women's flesh, their smoke habits, the pills they took, the bleeding of their bodies, the movement of their limbs in leisure.

They built models from numbers, complex as cathedral windows, adjusting for the confusion of facts that plague all seeking of truth. Age and smoke and flesh and movement, all accounted for in their equations.

In the end the numbers spoke clear as blood on sand. Those who followed the old ways, who ate as their Mediterranean ancestors ate, they lived longer. Their hearts stayed stronger. Their blood flowed true through unthreatened channels. Two thousand three hundred ninety-one hearts failed. One thousand seven hundred sixty-three minds lost their rivers of blood. One thousand seventy-seven returned to dust from these causes combined. But those who ate true to the old ways, they endured. Their risk fell like autumn leaves, scattered by winds of statistical significance.

Hitler lives, the sign read. Just that and nothing more.

The girl stood at the corner holding cardboard above her head like some prophet of old, dark letters bleeding into the fiber. Burma they call it now. Myanmar too. Names dont matter much when blood runs in gutters. The junta came in 62 and they came with guns and tanks and the old order fell like dead leaves in autumn. Aint nothing new under the sun.

They marched in 2007, them monks in robes color of dying sun. Saffron they called it. First time anyone dared march in ten years and the monks led them like Christ leading lambs. Military let them be at first but violence has its own rhythm, its own heartbeat. Soon enough the guns came out and the monasteries burned. They hunted journalists like coyotes hunt rabbits. Shot that Japanese man Nagai dead in the street for nothing more than holding a camera. Official count says thirteen dead but the colonel who run off told different. Bodies in the thousands he said. Just numbers now. Numbers dont mean nothing to the dead.

Been that way since men first gathered in tribes. Roman emperors claimed divine right same as Japanese ones did. Same as all tyrants do. Even now they wave their papers and hold their meetings, talking to god on golden telephone lines, telling the people what the lord wants. Aint nothing changed since Caesars time.

Square in China filled with students and workers in 89. Tank tracks on concrete and blood mixing with rain. Government says few hundred. Red Cross says thousands. Rwanda saw neighbors killing neighbors, machetes in the dawn light. Hitler and his reich burning people like cordwood. World keeps turning. Sun rises on the dead same as the living.

The girl stands there still with her sign. Words dont change nothing but still she stands. Sometimes standing is all we got left.

They say Duke Ellington carried jazz in his bones and the weight of that music bore down through the years like some ancient thing passed from father to son in the dark of night. His fingers moved across ivory keys quiet as windblown snow while the compositions he birthed came forth like fever dreams, rich and strange and filled with the voices of men who'd signed their souls to his orchestra. Each piece a framework built of notes and carried on the wind, and within that framework men could dance their solos wild and free or march in lockstep precise as soldiers to war.

The way he wrote was like a man who knew the hearts of his players better than they knew themselves. Each note crafted special for the particular demon that lived in their horns, in their fingers, in their breath. The sound would rise up whole and pure like something torn from the earth itself.

They wrote of him in Grove, them scholars of sound, speaking of Creole Love Call like witnesses to some strange ceremony. Voice become instrument, wordless and pure. The piece moved like this: First the voice crying out smooth as silk then turning rough as gravel, the reeds answering back like lost souls. Then came the trumpet, muted and blue as midnight, followed by clarinet sailing high above like some night bird. The whole band rose up then, brass and reed calling back and forth like wolves in darkness. At the height of it all the reeds screamed high and wild while brass and rhythm punched holes in time itself. Then back to voice and reed once more, the voice growling like some trapped thing, before it all ended in dissonance and darkness.

A year later came Hot and Bothered, Miley's muted trumpet crying out to Baby Cox's voice, instrument and human throat tangled together like lovers. Later still It Don't Mean a Thing rose up with Nanton's trombone leading the way like some twisted prophet. The sound of it all carrying forward through time like echoes in a cave, bearing witness to what jazz was and what it could become.

They say evolution moves like a river but that aint right. It moves like blood in the veins of some ancient thing, coursing through time without memory or purpose. In 1917 Thompson wrote that we hadnt even begun to speak of living things in numbers and equations and maybe we still aint. The truth of it lies somewhere in the bones of things, in the slow accretion of shell and matter, in the geometric prophecies written in calcium and time.

We took to studying these shells called Prunum, their shapes like God's own mathematics spiraling out into darkness. The xray images showed their ghostly forms like photographs of souls departing. We fed these numbers into machines, made digital phantoms of what could be, what might have been. The boundaries of possibility written in code.

A shell aint nothing but a tube moving through space like some cosmic dance, turning round and round in degrees measured by men who think numbers can capture the essence of things. These turns we call whorls like the whorls of a fingerprint left by creation itself. They spiral round a center that aint there, a columella, holy and empty as a church at midnight. The last whorl always the biggest like the final word in some argument with time itself.

You can hold these shells and turn them any way you want. Apical, basal, apertural. Words we made up to pretend we understand. But the truth is in the counting of the whorls, in drawing lines across their faces like reading the age rings of trees or the marks on a prisoner's wall. Each shell nothing but a series of doors opening into time, each aperture a moment frozen in calcium carbonate, each mathematical coordinate a point on some map leading nowhere and everywhere at once.

And when we write these things down in numbers and equations we aint really capturing the thing itself but just its shadow on the cave wall of our understanding. The mathematics of it all just another way of trying to speak the language of whatever god or devil designed such geometries.

They watched the numbers like dark harbingers, unchanging and merciless across the Indonesian archipelago. Ten years gone and the dead infants still came, regular as the tides, while mothers lay bleeding in bamboo huts and concrete hospitals alike. Progress marched in some quarters - water flowing clean now where once it ran thick with death, but the children and their bearers paid their toll all the same, numbers scratched in ledgers far from the birthing rooms where life and death played their ancient game.

Midwives came more frequent now, seven of ten births seeing their weathered hands, but they stood powerless before the complications that turned routine delivery to tragedy. Blood flowing unchecked, staining dirt floors and sterile sheets without distinction. The numbers told lies of improvement while truth lay in the graves.

In the cities they cut mothers open when needed, steel against flesh, seven percent saved this way. But in the villages only two in hundred felt the knife's mercy. The division lay stark as lightning against a black sky - wealth and poverty, city and countryside, each marking their territories in infant breaths and mother's tears. Twenty-seven percent separated rich from poor in who lived and who died, coin and paper determining fate as surely as any god.

They argued in offices about solutions, program-specific approaches versus systemic change, while blood continued flowing and babies drew their last breaths. Vertical approaches promised quick victories, neat columns of improvement in official reports. But such solutions carried their own poison, drawing resources like vultures to fresh kill, leaving other needs to wither and die. They'd seen it before - AIDS programs swallowing family planning whole, duplicate services sprouting like weeds after rain, paperwork multiplying like some bureaucratic plague. All while mothers waited, and babies died, and the numbers remained unchanging as stone.

The thing about Popular Music aint that it grew or changed but that it mutated like some dark creature beneath the earth, spreading its tendrils through a hundred years of human suffering and joy until there wasnt no way to count its manifestations anymore. You got your rap and your rock and your country and jazz and folk music but they aint pure no more, each one spawning bastard children of their own kind, darker and stranger with each passing generation.

Heavy Metal came crawling out of this darkness some forty years past and it grew teeth. It grew claws. It showed mankind what music could be when you fed it raw meat and gunpowder, when you let it loose in the night to hunt. They say its expressive but what it expresses aint the kind of things decent folk want expressed. It deals in shadow and blood and the places where God dont look no more.

These days you cant hardly tell what Metal is anymore. Like some shapeshifter in them old stories it takes whatever form suits it, borrowing pieces of other music like a crow stealing bright things for its nest. To know Metal you got to know where it came from, got to understand that it aint just music but something that moves through the world like a fever through the blood.

Metal lives in the dark places. It demands more of everything - more noise more violence more skill with the instruments that make its unholy sounds. Them that play it aint amateurs but dark priests of their craft. Back in the seventies when the drugs came flooding in like a biblical plague the music got stranger still, like it was speaking in tongues nobody was meant to understand. They made records that sounded like messages from some other world, a world where the sun never rises and everything beautiful is broken. Even them Beatles, them nice boys from Liverpool, they got touched by it. Helter Skelter they called it, like they was naming some demon they'd conjured up, trying to outdo them Stones in darkness and weight.

In the years before the dreamers took to their canvases with their strange visions the man Rousseau had already begun to paint his own. The dreams came to him like thieves in the night and he put them down with careful strokes as if marking the passage of time itself. The painting called The Dream came in 1910 and in it lay not just some woman caught in the spell of strange lands but the very essence of Rousseau's own yearnings that had haunted him through the years. Recognition. Acceptance. Praise. These things moved through his mind like wraiths and led him down paths that forked and split until he knew not which way to turn.

He was born to a tinsmith in Laval where the spring rains fell hard on the slate roofs and the streets ran wet with the tears of commerce. No teacher showed him the ways of art and color and light. Instead he walked the cobbled streets as a gabelou collecting coins from the carts and wagons that passed through the gates of the city while the years spun past like leaves in autumn wind. Death came for his children. Eight small souls claimed before their time. Then it took his Clémence and left him with only Julia and the vast emptiness that follows such losses. He turned to painting like a man turns to drink, seeking solace in the colors and shapes that flowed from his brush.

The art world was not kind to such men as he. While others who had learned their craft in schools and academies gained fame and fortune he remained in shadows. Matisse had already begun to make his name when Rousseau finally found some small measure of recognition. They were as different as earth and sky these two. Matisse painted with fury against convention while Rousseau sought only to be embraced by it. Like a child seeking approval from stern parents he painted and waited and hoped while the critics passed him by with scarce a glance.

The common folk saw themselves in his work though he never meant it so. He painted what he saw in dreams and memories while others painted peasants with romantic eyes. His was the art of truth though none could see it then. The truth of a man who carried his dreams like stones in his pockets, weighing him down even as they gave him purpose.

They'd spoken of it before, these men of letters, how truth and beauty walked the same path like brothers in the desert night. Not separate things but one thing, moving through time like a snake through sand leaving only the faintest trace of its passing. Keats knew it when he wrote of that ancient urn, speaking truth to beauty and beauty to truth, and that was all there was and all there needed to be.

The things we know come to us through books and time and the hard lessons of years, but this knowing of beauty and right action comes unbidden like rain in August. We don't learn it. It's already there waiting to be found like old bones in the earth. When we speak of these things we ain't prescribing nothing. We're just trying to describe what's already there, been there since before any of us drew breath.

You can talk about the Mona Lisa all day long. Talk about her smile and them mountains behind her and what Leonardo was thinking when he painted her. But that ain't it. That ain't never been it. People stand before her and they say there's just something about her and that something is the truth of it. Same with what's right and wrong. You can write all the books you want about it but you ain't never gonna capture it complete. O'Connor knew it. Said a story was the only way to say the things that couldn't be said no other way. Like trying to describe the wind. You can talk about what it moves and what it destroys but you ain't never gonna catch it in your hands.

The truth of it is that beauty and morality are like two horses running the same trail in the dark. You can't see em proper but you know they're there. You feel em in your bones like thunder. Kant called it noumenal. Something you could know but never explain. Like how a man knows right from wrong before he ever learns the words for either. The writers know it best. They know that words on paper ain't just about making pretty sounds. They're about showing us what's true and what's right, even if we can't say exactly why. That's what makes em matter. That's what makes em real.

The Germany that stands now rises like some ancient colossus from the earth itself, a thing wrought from blood and iron and time immemorial. From the shadow-haunted peaks of München where the alps rear against god's own sky down to where Kiel's dark waters lap at shores older than memory. The land speaks its own tongue from Köln where the Rhine cuts deep through history to Dresden squatting like some Saxon sentinel on the Elbe's banks. This place, this Germany, it carries in its soil the bones of a thousand tribes, each one leaving its mark like brands upon cattle.

Germania they called it, those ancient ones who first put name to this wild place. The scholars and learned men they argue still about what that name means, their words falling like dead leaves in autumn winds. Tacitus, that Roman who wrote of savage lands, he said the name came from the Tungrians, fierce warriors who crossed the Rhine and fought the Gauls until their blood ran into the earth. Caesar too, he spoke of these Germans, wrote of them in his accounts of war and conquest. He took the word from Gaulish tongues, marking those he'd beaten from those who stood yet unconquered. Some say it meant neighbor in that old speech, others claim it spoke of their spears, those terrible gers that drank deep of Roman blood, or maybe it came from their battle cries that echoed through forests primeval.

Tacitus wrote more, in that year ninety-eight after their Christ, speaking of these Germans as if they'd sprung full-formed from the black soil itself. No mixing of blood, he said, no wanderers come seeking better lands. For who would choose such a place, he asked, with its wild woods and bitter skies, unless it was already carved into their very bones?

And indeed what Roman would venture here save by order or madness? They came for plunder and glory, leading their legions through trackless woods, but always they returned to their marble cities and warm wines. The Germans, they lived there in the shadows of empire, trading what the land gave up and selling their strength to Rome's armies, their blood mixing with the soil that would one day bear their name.

The stage holds truth and lies both, and in Twelfth Night they dance together like snakes in the dust, writhing and coiling until you cant tell where one ends and the other begins. The masks we wear they protect us yes but they eat at the soul like acid on metal and in time there aint nothing left of what you were before. Some folk they take kind to learning theyve been fooled but others theyll cut you deep for such betrayal and there aint no going back from that kind of wound.

When a woman puts on mans clothes its like staring into a dark mirror that shows all manner of uncomfortable truths. Viola she done what she had to do, surviving like a wounded animal in strange territory. The captain helped her yes, gave her mens clothes like armor against the world that would tear her apart otherwise. But armor weighs heavy and in time it leaves marks that dont heal.

She walked among them like a ghost between worlds. The women they turned from her not knowing she was their kind and Olivia god help her she fell into loving what wasnt there to love at all. Husband she called her, that word hanging in the air like gunsmoke. And Orsino he spoke of love too, words spilling out like blood from an old wound, telling this boy-that-wasnt how no woman could match such devotion.

There's them that might say Shakespeare was showing us something about the nature of want and desire, how it lives in dark places we dont care to look at. Olivia seeing what she wanted to see, loving a shadow of a thing that never was. Maybe she loved the woman beneath them boys clothes or maybe she just loved the lie of it all. But when Sebastian come along looking like the ghost of that lie made flesh she took to him quick as a rattler strikes, and Viola became sister instead of lover, the way the world rights itself after a storm.

They spoke of the German rule in those lands and how it carried a darkness with it, a darkness that found its fullest expression in the killing of the Ovaherero and the Nama people. But empires aint simple things and cant be marked by single deeds no matter how terrible. The Germans ruled different in different places and they ruled according to the land and according to what they thought of the people who lived there.

In the eastern territories they built schools and taught the natives to read and when the British came in 1919 they found africans who could write their names in perfect german script. But in the southwest territories it wasnt like that at all. No it wasnt like that at all.

The southwest was different. There the government gave the teaching of natives over to the missionaries who worked with what little they were given while the white children went to fine schools built with government money. These things dont die. They go on and on through the years like a curse laid upon the land. While other colonies had natives who could read books and write letters the southwest stayed in darkness. Ignorant. Unable to read the words that condemned them.

The old books tell what happened. Most written in german and yellowed now with age. They tell how things were different in different places but they dont tell why. Later books written in english tried to explain it. A man named Cohen wrote on it. He said it was the settlers that made it different. More of them in the southwest than anywhere else in the german colonies.

The southwest was good country for whites. Not too hot. Desert yes but a desert a white man could live in. By 1913 there were fifteen thousand of them there. In the east where it was hotter and the land was different there wasnt but five thousand. The whites in the southwest they wanted things a certain way. They got what they wanted.

They stood there the two nations like ancient enemies across a dried riverbed of time and blood. Fifty-seven years they warred and feuded, from eighteen thirty-six until eighteen ninety-three, the high water mark being that war of forty-six where American boys marched south and took what wasnt theirs to take. Texas and the lands beyond. Sacred ground stained with the blood of generations. The people different as night and day, their gods different too.

The world is full of such neighbors. Full of such feuds. Nations that share borders share bloodshed like communion wine. Mexico and these United States aint special in that regard. Only Mexico and Cuba, someone once wrote, only they caused such lasting trouble for the American dream. Both of them close enough to touch. Close enough to hate.

Religion ran deep like a poison well between them. Where Americans feared the papal crown and catholic cross in them days like they'd later fear the communist star, inheriting old hatreds from across the sea where English and Spanish had warred before them. Ancient grudges passed down like family heirlooms, poisoning any chance of peace.

Seventeen times they clashed proper in them fifty-seven years. Most times over land and borders where outlaws and murderers crossed back and forth like desert wolves, preying on both sides until both nations sent their armies to hunt them down. The armies met too sometimes, these encounters writ in blood across the dusty pages of history.

In the end it wasnt peace that stopped the killing but money. Mexico grew dependent on American coin like a man grows dependent on water in the desert. The United States no longer hungered for land but for profit, and slowly the old wounds scabbed over though they never truly healed. Some say they never will.

Fifteen years back the sickness came. Not gradual like most afflictions but sudden and complete, a thief in the night stealing what was mine to keep. I didn't even know such a malady existed in this world.

I wore white then. Moved through antiseptic halls ministering to the sick and dying. Chose that path from some deep-seated need for sanctuary, the kind that eluded me in youth. They'd say: Work will always find you, for the sick walk among us eternal. So I buried my dreams of science and words and took up the mantle of healing.

Then there I stood. Forty-six winters gone, alone, coffers empty as a desert well, unable to labor. Still am. Fifteen years living off government scraps has stripped me bare of possessions and pride alike. Each dawn brings its own war against security and worth. Nothing certain now save uncertainty itself. Yet this truth remains: survival came not from personal fortitude but through the mercy of blood kin and true friends. When calamity visits, it takes all strength just to breathe.

Life brings its catastrophes, big and small as grains of sand. No guarantees in this world. No preparation sufficient against its largest storms. We cant weather them alone.

True enough we need less faith in government's rotting basket. But better to learn trust in our fellow man than to dig individual holes in the earth like scared rabbits. They speak of rugged individualism building this nation but that aint the truth of it. What carried our ancestors through was mercy and mutual aid and the sharing of what little they had. Them pioneer wagons didnt cross the mountains one by one.

Be ready, yes. Keep your emergency stores. Your medical supplies and water tablets and window coverings against whatever poison might come floating on the wind. Keep your lights and batteries and matches sealed against the wet. Store food if you can. Plant if you got earth to plant in. Heat with wood if walls allow.

But know your neighbor too. For in the end that's all we got.

In the old world, in times before memory, a prince drew breath who would come to be known as Buddha. He walked away from all he knew into darkness and returned with light in his eyes. His words spread like fire through dry grass and from them grew Buddhism, its purest form called Theravada. Twenty-five hundred years have passed and time has worked its violence upon the teachings as it does upon all things. In Sri Lanka they cut water now in ceremony, monks and common folk alike moving through rituals Buddha never spoke of, never dreamed. The changes run deeper than mere ceremony. They run to the bone and marrow of what salvation means.

The words we use matter. Internal and external like the inside and outside of a skull. Internal being those who walk the Buddha's path, external being those who dont. Some forces come with knives drawn, meaning harm. Others pass by like storms that neither know nor care what stands in their path but may still tear down temples or plant seeds in their passing. These words will walk with us through what follows.

The heart of it beats thus: Three jewels they call them. Buddha. Dhamma. Sangha. The Dhamma held in three vessels, three baskets of words passed down. The Suttas speak of teachings. The Vinaya speaks of rules. The Abhidhamma speaks of what lies beyond the world we know. They tell of how no soul exists eternal, how suffering dogs all life like a shadow, how nothing lasts. Know these things and you might break free from the wheel that turns life into death into life again. Break free from want and hate and the fog that clouds mens minds. The Vinaya sets down the law. For common folk five rules: kill nothing, speak true, take nothing not given, keep the flesh holy, shun the spirits that cloud the mind. For monks the rules run deeper, darker. But at the core lie four truths simple as stones: Life is suffering. Want breeds suffering. Suffering can end. These truths carve the path through darkness.
